entry.title: Configuring SAP Cloud Identity Services and Microsoft Entra ID for Joule
entry.content:
This blog provides a step-by-step guide on configuring Microsoft Entra ID as your corporate identity provider for SAP BTP applications. You must configure both Microsoft Entra ID and SAP Cloud Identity Services to trust each other. We're going to configure this trust using OpenID Connect as the protocol. For the purposes of this blog, we are performing this configuration for Joule. When users access Joule, they'll be redirected to SAP Cloud Identity Services and then forwarded to your corporate identity provider, Microsoft Entra ID, for authentication. 

This configuration is a first step required to integrate Joule with Microsoft Copilot and Teams. We provide the integration Joule with Microsoft Copilot and Teams in a second blog. After this integration, your users can start conversational interactions with Joule apps in Microsoft Copilot or Teams, which pass these queries on to Joule agents.

Prerequisites

  • You have an SAP BTP global account with SAP Cloud Identity Services as the custom identity provider.
    For more information, see SAP BTP Administrator's Guide.
  • You have subscribed to Joule.
    For more information, see Initial Setup for Joule.
  • You have a tenant of Microsoft Entra ID.

Collect the Required Information

In the following sections you need to know the issuer URLs for your SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant and your Microsoft Entra ID tenant. We use the following placeholders for these URLs.

  • Entra ID issuer: {entraid_issuer}
  • SAP Cloud Identity Services issuer: {cloud_identity_issuer}

Issuer and Tenant ID of Your Entra ID Tenant

You can derive your Entra ID issuer from the tenant ID and the following URL pattern:

{entraid_issuer} = https://login.microsoftonline.com/{entraid_tenant_id}/v2.0 

Get the Tenant ID of Your Microsoft Entra ID Tenant

Go to the Microsoft Entra Admin Center with the admin user role.

  1. Go to Home > Manage tenants
  2. Note down the Tenant ID.
    Use this value for the placeholder {entraid_tenant_id}.

Issuer and Subdomain of Your SAP Cloud Identity Services Tenant

In the SAP public cloud offering, the issuer of your SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant follows one the following patterns: 

  • {cloud_identity_issuer} = https://{cloud_identity_tenant_subdomain}.accounts.ondemand.com (default)
  • {cloud_identity_issuer} = https://{cloud_identity_tenant_subdomain}.accounts.cloud.sap
  • {cloud_identity_issuer} = https://{custom-domain} 

Note: 

  • The {cloud_identity_issuer} doesn't have a trailing slash.
  • For SAP private cloud offerings, the values may differ.
    Alternatively, you can find all domains of your SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant in the admin console under Applications & Resources > Tenant Settings > Single Sign-On > OpenID Connect Configuration > Identity Provider Settings.
    Under Domain for Browser Flows you find the value Default in addition to the list of all domains under which the SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant can be reached.

Get the Issuer for SAP Cloud Identity Services

  1. Open the OpenID Connect configuration endpoint in your browser using one of the domains under which you typically access your SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant and add the path .well-known/openid-configuration.
    For SAP public cloud the URL use the following pattern:
    https://{cloud_Identity_tenant_subdomain}.accounts.ondemand.com/.well-known/openid-configuration
  2. Use the value provided for issuer as {cloud_identity_issuer}.

Configure Microsoft Entra ID

Go to the Entra ID Admin Center with the admin user role.

Register the Federation App

  1. Go to Home > Identity > Applications > App registrations.
  2. Choose New registration.
  3. Enter a meaningful name such as Federation with {cloud_identity_issuer}.
  4. Under Redirect URI (optional), choose Web.
  5. Enter the following redirect URI: {cloud_identity_issuer}/oauth2/callback.
    Replace the placeholder with the proper value.
  6. Choose Register.
  7. Note down the Application (client) ID and the Directory (tenant) ID.
    You need the application ID later in this blog and the follow up blog. The directory ID is needed only in the follow up blog. 

Configure Redirect URIs

Add all remaining redirect URIs that are supported by your SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant to the application registration. See the previous section Issuer and Subdomain of Your SAP Cloud Identity Services Tenant.

  1. Go to Authentication.
  2. Under Platform configurations  > Web, choose Add URI.
  3. Add the additional redirect URIs.
    • For SAP public cloud, enter:
      • https://{cloud_identity_tenant_subdomain}.accounts.ondemand.com/oauth2/callback
      • https://{cloud_identity_tenant_subdomain}.accounts.cloud.sap/oauth2/callback
    • When using a custom domain, enter: https://{custom-domain}/oauth2/callback
  4. Save your entries.

Add Federated Credentials

  1. Choose Certificates & secrets.
  2. Choose Federated credentials and choose Add credential.
  3. Under Federated credential scenario, choose Other issuer.
  4. Under Connect your account, enter the following values for the parameters:
    ParameterValue
    Issuer{cloud_identity_issuer}
    TypeExplicit subject identifier
    Value

    Federation with Entra ID

    Note: Remember this value. You'll need this value later when you configure SAP Cloud Identity Services to trust this tenant.

     
  5. Under Credential Details, enter the following values for the parameters:
    ParameterValue
    NameCredential-for-SCI-Tenant
    DescriptionCredential-for-SCI-Tenant
    Audience{entraid_issuer}

  6. Choose Add.

Configure Tokens

  1. Go to Token configuration.
  2. Choose Add optional claim.
  3. Under Token type, choose Access.
  4. Enable the email claim and choose Add.
  5. Choose Add.

Add API Permissions

  1. Go to API permissions.
  2. Choose Add a permission.
  3. Choose Microsoft Graph.
  4. Choose Delegated permissions.
  5. Under OpenId permissions enable all 4 permissions: email, offline_access, openid, profile.
  6. Choose Add permissions.
    The console displays the new permissions in the Configured permissions table. Some of the permissions may not be granted yet.
  7. Choose Grant admin consent for {your_Entra_ID_tenant}.
  8. Choose Yes.
  9. Verify that all permissions have the granted status.

Expose APIs

  1. Go to Expose an API.
  2. Under Application ID URI, choose Add.
  3. Enter the URI using the following pattern:
    api://{cloud_identity_tenant_subdomain}.accounts.cloud.sap
    Note: Make sure that this identifier ends with .accounts.cloud.sap!
  4. Save your entries.
  5. Under Scopes defined by this API, choose Add a scope.
  6. In the Scope name fied, enter access_as_user.
  7. Provide a consent display name and a consent description.
  8. Choose Add scope.

Add Manifests

  1. Go to Manifest.
  2. Choose Microsoft Graph App Manifest (new).
  3. Search for requestedAccessTokenVersion and set its value to 2.
  4. Save your entries.
  5. Choose AAD Graph App Manifest (Deprecating Soon).
  6. Search for accessTokenAcceptedVersion and set its value to 2.
  7. Save your entries.

Configure SAP Cloud Identity Services

You must know the {entraid_issuer} and ApplicationId, which you noted down during the registration of your federation app in Microsoft Entra ID.

Go to the SAP Cloud Identity Services Administration Console with the admin user role.

Create a Corporate Identity Provider

  1. Go to Identity Providers > Corporate Identity Providers.
  2. Choose Create.
  3. Enter the following values:
    FieldValue
    Display NameFederation with Entra ID
    Identity Provider TypeOpenID Connect Compliant
    Copy Settings from Identity ProviderDon’t copy (default)
     
  4. Choose Create.

Configure Subject Name Identifier

  1. Choose Trust > Subject Name Identifier.
  2. Choose Email.
  3. Save your entries.

Configure Identity Federation

  1. Choose Trust > Single Sign-On > Identity Federation.
  2. Enable Use Identity Authentication user store.
  3. Enable Allow Identity Authentication users only.

Configure OpenID Connect    

In this step, you must know the values for {entraid_issuer} and ApplicationId which you noted down during the registration of your federation app in Microsoft Entra ID.

  1. Choose Trust > OpenID Connect Configuration.
  2. Under Provider Configuration, enter the following:
    FieldValue
    Discover URL{entraid_issuer} /.well-known/openid-configuration
    Name

    Federation with Entra ID

    Note: The value of this field must the same as the Value field configured in the federated credential in Microsoft Entra ID. If you leave this field empty, the system will enter the value for you when you load the configuration later in this procedure.

    Metadata Refresh Interval

    24 hours

      
  3. Under Client Authentication > Client Authentication Method choose Client assertion in body.
  4.  Under Client Authentication > Client ID, enter the ApplicationId from the federation app in Microsoft Entra ID.
  5. Add the following Scopes:
    • email
    • profile
    • offline_access
  6. Chose Load (next to the Discovery URL).
    The system reads the value of the Value field associated with the name configured in the federated credential on Microsoft Entra ID and enters the value as the name of the provider configuration, as long as you didn't enter a name previously. The system also enters the endpoints for the configuration. 
  7. Save your entries.

Validate the Configuration in SAP Cloud Identity Services

  1. In the OpenID Connect Configuration of your corporate identity provider, choose Validate.
    A new tab appears with a sign in prompt from Microsoft Entra ID.
  2. Sign on with a user with an admin role.
    If asked to grant permissions, choose Accept.

        
  3. Verify the success of the validation.
    • Step 1 – Authorization Code shows Success.
    • Step 2 – Token shows Success.
      The following Scopes are listed: email, openid, profile, User.Read.
    • Step 3 – TokenVerification shows Success.

Configure Microsoft Entra ID as Identity Provider for Joule

Prerequisites

  • Tenant configuration setup
    You have configured a federated trust between SAP Cloud Identity Service and Microsoft Entra ID using OpenID Connect.
  • Joule subscription
    You have subscribed to Joule.

Configuration in SAP Cloud Identity Services

Go to the SAP Cloud Identity Services administration console with the admin user role.

Configure your Microsoft Entra ID tenant as the identity provider for Joule and related applications from which Joule launches. You have the choice of setting up your Microsoft Entra ID as the default authenticating identity provider or by setting up conditional authentication for when only part of the user base is on that identity provider.

  1.  Choose Applications & Resources > {your_joule-app}.
    The application has the following pattern: das-ias ({subaccount_name}).
  2. Choose Conditional Authentication.
    • Option 1: Set Microsoft Entra ID as the Default Authenticating Identity Provider
      1. In the Default Identity Provider field, choose Federation with Entra ID.
      2. Save your entries.
    • Option 2: Setup Conditional Authentication for Joule 
      1. Choose Add Rule.
      2. Under Identity Provider, choose Federation with Entra ID.
      3. In Email Domain, enter the email domain of the users in your Microsoft Entra ID.
      4. Choose OK.
      5. Save your entries.
        Verify that there is a new rule for your identity provider.

Conclusion

Users can access Joule and authenticate with your Microsoft Entra ID corporate identity provider. 

Next integrate Joule with Microsoft Copilot and Teams so that your users can have conversational interactions that include content about integrated SAP systems. See Enable Microsoft Copilot and Teams to Pass Requests to Joule.

entry.title: Enable Microsoft Copilot and Teams to Pass Requests to Joule
entry.content:
This blog shows you how to integrate Joule with Microsoft Copilot and Teams so that your users can have conversational interactions that include content about integrated SAP systems. With the previous blog, we established the technical infrastructure so that Microsoft and SAP systems trust each other and exchange any required tokens for the two systems to interact. In the next steps, we add SAP's Teams Bot, add the required API permissions, then expose those APIs. In the final step, you add M365 Copilot for Joule to your landscape to complete the integration.

The following figure shows our target architecture.

Prerequisites

  • You've configured your tenants SAP Cloud Identity Services and Microsoft Entra ID to trust each other. 
    You need the TenantId which you noted down during the registration of your federation app in Microsoft Entra ID.
  • You've set up conditional authentication for Joule.

For details, see our previous blog Configuring SAP Cloud Identity Services and Microsoft Entra ID for Joule.

Configure Your Microsoft Entra ID Tenant

Go to the Entra ID Admin Center with the admin user role.

Add the SAP Teams-Bot Application

  1. Open a text editor and copy this URL:
    https://login.microsoftonline.com/    <tenant_id>/v2.0/adminconsent?client_id=2cf32c47-cb71-49f6-a648-d8fe234042f8&scope=2cf32c47-cb71-49f6-a648-d8fe234042f8/.default
  2. Replace <tenant_id> with the directory (tenant) ID which you noted down during the registration of your federation app in Microsoft Entra ID in our previous blog Configuring SAP Cloud Identity Services and Microsoft Entra ID for Joule.
  3. Open a browser, paste the URL and execute the request.
  4. Log on with a user with the admin user role.
    A consent dialog appears.
  5. Give your consent (accept).
    You can ignore error messages displayed in the browser.

Configure API Permissions

  1. Go to Home > Identity > Applications > App registrations.
  2. Choose your federation app.
  3. Choose API permissions.
  4. Choose Add a permission.
  5. Choose APIs my organization uses.
  6. Choose svc-ai-joule-prod.
  7. Choose Delegated Permissions (default).
  8. Enable the access_as_user permission.
  9. Choose Add permissions.

    Notice the new entry for svc-ai-joule-prod. Permissions aren't granted yet.
  10. Choose Grant admin consent for {Entra_ID_Tenant_Name} and choose Yes.
  11. Verify that the status for svc-ai-joule-prod has changed to Granted.

Expose APIs

  1. Go to Home > Identity > Applications > App registrations.
  2. Choose your federation app.
  3. Choose Expose an API.
  4. Validate that you have already added the Application ID URI as described in our previous blog Configuring SAP Cloud Identity Services and Microsoft Entra ID for Joule.
  5. Choose Add client application and add the following client applications:
    • 2cf32c47-cb71-49f6-a648-d8fe234042f8 (SAP Teams-Bot application)
    • 1fec8e78-bce4-4aaf-ab1b-5451cc387264 (Teams Desktop Application)
    • 5e3ce6c0-2b1f-4285-8d4b-75ee78787346 (Teams Mobile Application)
  6. Enable any Authorized scopes.
  7. Choose Add application.
  8. Verify that all three applications are listed under Authorized client applications.

Enable the Joule Application for Microsoft Copilot and Teams

Use the Joule Booster to add a system of type Microsoft 365 Copilot for SAP Joule to your system landscape and add this system to your Joule formation.

For more information, see Run the Joule Booster in the Joule Documentation.

See also Enabling Joule in the SAP BTP Documentation.

Give it a Go

If everything is configured correctly, you can open the Joule application in Microsoft Copilot or Microsoft Teams and say, "Hello". Joule should answer back. If Joule doesn't answer, you might have made a mistake in following these blogs or we may have a bug to iron out. Go carefully through this setup and make sure you have it right. If you are still having trouble, our support team will be happy to help you. Use support component CLT-COP.

Conclusion

Your landscape is configured to pass on conversations started in a Joule application in Microsoft Copilot and Teams to a Joule agent, which in turn queries further Joule agents integrated with the landscape.

entry.title: My AI Experience Sharing – Setting up Joule for the S/4HANA Public Edition (Part A: Preparation)
entry.content:
Introduction

Now Artificial Intelligence (AI) is on every professional’s mind. Everybody wants to be on the bandwagon.  I plan to write a series of blogs on this topic under a big umbrella “My AI Experience Sharing”.  This is the first mini-series: setting up Joule for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. 

I purposely delayed my action on setting up a Joule to wait for the dust settling down during the Early Adopter phase. The intention paid off but still won’t give me a free pass 😉. There are five credible references available as listed in the Reference section, but none of them give you a good explanation on Why, especially on What in a critical step with a readable picture when you desperately need a hint.  To help all the people like me, this blog will focus on explaining those steps, what to enter, and possible mistakes to avoid. 

Note 1: The content here is drawn from my direct experience from setting up Joule for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (more than five times and still counting). It might be true for other SAP solutions but only use that as a reference so that I don’t feel the pressure of entire SAP world on my shoulder 😁.

Note 2: Since there are a lot of topics to discuss, I divided the mini-series into Part A Preparation,  Part B Joule Installation and Part C Deinstallation. 

Note 3: The systems I used in this mini-series are:

  • BTP Global Account: 2024-09 3SL Account
  • BTP Joule Subaccount: PSCC-AMER-3SL-PRD
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Production tenant G4X/100, http://myxxxxxxx.s4hana.cloud.sap/ 
  • Cloud Identity Services: Provisioned together with above BTP and Public Cloud tenants, xxxxxxxx.accounts.ondemand.com

Note 4: Considering some customers and consultants need to deinstall and reinstall Joule for many reasons like practicing the installation, correcting an unsuccessful installation, etc., I am adding a new blog Part C: Deinstallation here for your reference.

 

Solution Architecture for Joule Running with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

Joule is an SAP AI Co-Pilot developed by SAP to work seamlessly with SAP solutions, such as the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (I will call it the Public Cloud for easy writing and reading).  It can guide you through content discovery in a format of natural language dialog (aka Generative AI).

To make the Joule working, we need to integrate SAP solution, Application Clients, SAP Cloud Identity Service (CIS) and SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) as shown below. In addition, Joule integrates with the SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition.  Essentially, Joule acts as a conversational interface within the Work Zone, empowering users to interact with SAP systems more intuitively and efficiently.

Solution Architecture for Joule Running with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

At a very high level, we can highlight some key points of the Solution Architecture to help us understand those steps to take in the set-up procedures:

  1. User access either the Public Cloud or the Joule through the Application Client, such as the web client.
  2. There is a Joule UI plug-in within the Application Client to access Joule.
  3. When a dialog is initiated in Joule, the later access the Public Cloud data through an OData API (green line).
  4. To make this API call successful, there is a pre-built trust between the Identity Authentication Service (IAS) and the Public Cloud, as well as the BTP. This needs to be configured.  Trust enables the SSO.
  5. Joule is integrated into the SAP Work Zone, enabling users to access Joule’s capabilities within their Work Zone environment.  Work Zone has access to the Public Cloud data.
  6. The Public Cloud provides the Content Data Model (CDM) meta data to the Work Zone.

One important thing here is that all three components (Public Cloud tenants, Identity Authentication Service Tenant and the SAP BTP Global Account) are associated with the same Customer Number to simplify the configuration. If this is not the case for you, see Reuse SAP Cloud Identity Services Tenants for Different Customer IDs in the documentation for Identity Authentication.  This is discussed in SAP Help Configure Trust to the Identity Authentication Tenant.

 

Major Setup Steps

By combining the information provided from five different references, I list 17 major steps, eight of them for preparation and nine for Joule Installation as shown in below two tables. Each table has four columns: Step (number), App (to run the step), Action (of the step) and Purpose (of the step).  You can use these two tables to guide you through the entire setup process.

Here are the abbreviations listed in each step:

  • DC1: Discovery Center: Establish a Unified Joule Instance
  • DC2: Discovery Center: Activate Joule with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • Blog1: Joule – End-to-End Setup Guide (for all Line of Business) Unified Approach
  • Blog2: Joule in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Setup Guide
  • SH: SAP Help: Joule onboarding guide

I mostly follow the steps outlined in the DC1 for Preparation and DC2 for Joule Installation, with the complimentary content from other references. Two blogs are informative, but screenshots are impossible to read.  The SAP Help is not sufficient to guide a successful setup.

 Eight Major Preparation Steps for Joule Setup in the Public Cloud

 

Ten Major Joule Installation Steps for Joule Setup in the Public Cloud

To make a sense of these steps, I pin the Steps A and Steps B on the original solution architecture diagram.

  Major Preparation and Joule Installation Steps for Joule Setup in the Public Cloud

 

Eight Major Preparation Steps Explained

In this section, I am going to explain all of preparation steps listed.  The hyperlink of each step gives a direct access to the document.

We can group Preparation Steps into five categories:

  • Steps A.1 – A.2: Verify all necessary information
  • Step A.3: Create a BTP subaccount for Joule installation
  • Steps A.4 – A.6: Build trusts among BTP, IAS and Public Cloud
  • Step A.7: Build and subscribe Work Zone
  • Step A.8: Add missing user attributes to BTP applications

 

Step A.1 DC1: Verify Global Account Entitlements

When you sign the contract to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, there are many line items called entitlements.  For example, SKU 8017178 is for Joule. With that, you can have Joule Entitlements in your BTP system. Make sure you have all the necessary entitlements before starting the set-up work, because it does take time to request additional entitlements if they are not there.

In my BTP Global Account “2024-09 3SL Account”, I have two Joule entitlement related plans (das stands for Digital Assistant Service; Joule is a product from SAP to serve the purpose of the Digital Assistant Service):

  1. das-application-canary
  2. das-application

The first plan was added in early April, 2025 after a change in Joule Booster by SAP. I used the 2nd Plan in March when there was only one Joule Booster.  In May, I had to use the 1st Plan to build another system.  I will discuss more about these plans later.

Joule Entitlements in the BTP Global Account

Besides Joule entitlement, you need SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition entitlement.  There is a difference between a foundation plan and a standard plan.  We will discuss later.

Entitlements of SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition

There are two Service Technical Names under the service SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition.  If you only have the build-workzone-standard plan, no SAPLaunchpad plan, no worry.  It worked for me as well.

The entitlements are added during the BTP system provision based on your CRM order (contract) information.  If you don’t have the necessary entitlements, contact your sales executive to correct it. 

 

Step A.2 DC1: Check S/4 HANA Public Cloud Tenant is Registered in BTP

This step is to build a communication binding between the BTP and the Public Cloud tenant with the following steps. The work is done on both sides: the BTP side as well as the Public Cloud Tenant side.

On the BTP side

Check if the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition tenant is registered under the System Landscape  System.  If your Public Cloud tenant is provisioned together with the BTP tenant, most probably, it is Auto-discovered and Registered.  Otherwise, just manually add the tenant here.

My four tenants are all registered as shown.

The SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Tenant is Registered in the BTP

 

On the Public Cloud Tenant Side

When the Public Cloud tenant is registered in the BTP, an Integration Token is generated. This Integration Token is used to create the Extension on the Public Cloud tenant side.  This way a solid binding is created between a Registered Public Cloud tenant in the BTP System Landscape and an Extension in the Public Cloud tenant.

An Extension for the Public Cloud Tenant Registered in the BTP

If you deregister the Public Cloud tenant in the BTP, the extension is removed on the Public Cloud tenant side automatically.  Then you need to re-register the system and get an integration token on the BTP; Re-create a new extension on the Public Cloud tenant.

 

Step A.3 Configure Subaccount in SAP BTP for Joule

In this step, we have three distinctive tasks:

  1. Create a dedicated Joule subaccount in the BTP Global Account.
    1. Create a subaccount (for this blog, my global account name is 2024-09 3SL Account, the subaccount name is PSCC-3SL-AMER-PRD)
    2. Enable the Cloud Foundry
    3. Create a Cloud Foundry space
  2. Create a Service Plan with the SAP Build Work Zone entitlements
  3. Add the Public Cloud tenant’s URL to the Trusted Domains list in the BTP subaccount.

The Cloud Foundry is a cloud application platform for building, testing, deploying, and scaling applications. In our case, we use it for Joule and Build Work Zone. By default, we get 200 GB space for it.

To add Service Plans to the SAP Build Work Zone, make sure you select below three plans for the Public Cloud: standard and standard (Application) instead of foundation and foundation (Application).  For the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, we don’t use any foundation plan for the Work Zone (see Blog 1: Joule – End-to-End Setup Guide (for all Line of Business) Unified Approach)

Here is the screenshot when you Add Service Plans.

Select Three Plans for the SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition

For the Trusted Domains, we add the URL like shown in the figure below.

Add the URL of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to the Trusted Domains List

Notes:

  1. When a subaccount is created in BTP, a new application is created in the IAS. However, it takes some time before the new application shows up. After it shows up, follow Step A.8 to add a new attribute Email_verified.
  2. When deleting a subaccount, make sure deleting all subscriptions, instances and environment first within the subaccount, then remove the subaccount itself.

 

As described at the Solution Architecture above, we need to establish a Trust among all three components: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, the Identity Authentication Service Tenant and the SAP BTP. In other words, we want to be able to use the Single Signed-On (SSO) to access one component from another without explicitly providing a username and the password.  The following two steps try to accomplish this.

  1. Step A.4: Add identity providers for applications to enable users to log on to applications consumed in this subaccount.
  2. Step A.5: Add identity providers for platform users used by administrators, operators, and developers to access platform tools and environments.

 

Step A.4 DC1: Establish Trust between Subaccount and SAP Cloud Identity Authentication Service

This step is to establish a trust between the BTP subaccount and the SAP Cloud Identity Authentication Service (IAS) to ensure a Single Sign-on (SSO) works.  Let me explain how this SSO works as illustrated in three steps in the below picture.

1: When a user clicks on the Joule icon, there is a logon process happening.  Since Joule is a plug in running on the SAP Build Work Zone, this task is in fact a Work Zone task.

2: Work Zone is part of the BTP subaccount, so it reaches out to the Trust information stored to find out which Identity Authentication Service it can rely on.  In this Joule Setup, it is the IAS tenant we are trying to store in this Step A.4.

3: The IAS verifies the user. If the user exists, the logon happens behind the scenes without your input. This is called Single Sign-On.  If the user does not exist, the logon fails, or the SSO fails, and a logon window pops up asking you to enter the user information. If a wrong IAS is stored as a Trust IAS, the logon fails as well (this is what we will discuss in length about the domain name below).

The Single Sign-On Explained for Joule Logon

This step is also presented in SAP Help: Joule onboarding guide - Configure Trust to the Identity Authentication Tenant and Blog: Joule – End-to-End Setup Guide (for all Line of Business) Unified Approach.  In SAP Help Configure Trust to the Identity Authentication Tenant, it has a note: “For single-sign on to work, the domain of the Identity Authentication tenant must be same as the corresponding SAP system trust setup.” 

In Section 7. Setup Trust Configuration with SAP Cloud Identity Service of the Blog, it has a good discussion about how to choose the domain name, and I am copying it here to highlight its importance.

(P)lease validate if your SAP applications URL is using the domain model “*.accounts.cloud.sap” or do you see “*.accounts.ondemand.com”, select the appropriate domain, and click Next.

Example:

SAP S/4HANA Cloud: http://myxxxxxxx.s4hana.cloud.sap/

In my case, all my SAP applications are using *.accounts.cloud.sap so I have opted for *.cloud.sap.

Both references talk about the same thing, but hard to understand!!!  Here is why: our IAS tenant for the Public Cloud is xxxx.accounts400.ondemand.com, not xxxx.accounts400.cloud.sap.  For a reason I still cannot find (!), you cannot use the Public Cloud IAS URL as the domain name as it is.  It is a twist to test my brain power 😀.

Enough explanation.  Let’s look at the Configure Tenant dialog box. In the dropdown list of the Domain, you have two choices/formats, the xxxx.accounts400.ondemand.com and the xxxx.accounts400.cloud.sap.  Which one to use? For the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, our tenant is in the format of myxxxxxx.s4hana.cloud.sap, so to be consistent, the domain name xxxx.accounts400.cloud.sap should be selected. For some other applications like SAP Success Factors, the xxxx.accounts400.ondemand.com is proper when the cloud application URL uses the format of xxxx.ondemand.com.

Choose a Proper Domain Format in the Configure Tenant Dialog Box

The newly created Trust is part of Custom Identity Provider for Applications in the subaccount as shown in the red box below.  All the Properties of this Trust are displayed on the right-hand side.  The red box highlights the Domain name xxxx.accounts400.cloud.sap.  You can Edit or Delete this Trust entry.

The Established Trust between the BTP Subaccount and the IAS

After the Trust is established, an application called SAP BTP subaccount PSCC-AMER-3SL-PRD is created in the SAP Cloud IAS.  Now we can use the SAP CIS as an identity provider to authenticate the users from this BTP subaccount. All the SSO related settings, such as Subject Name Identifier and Attributes, are present there. Details to be discussed in Step A.8.

The BTP Subaccount PSCC-AMER-3SL-PRD related application in the SAP Cloud IAS

Let me show you an example how this Trust doesn’t work: When you click on the Joule icon in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, based on your user information, the system tries to logon to the Joule service on the BTP subaccount with a Single Sign-on.  The authentication is carried out by your IAS on behalf of the BTP subaccount.  When a wrong IAS domain is provided (I purposely used the domain name “*.accounts.ondemand.com”), the SSO cannot carry on, and the below Sign In window pops up.  From the text string below Sign In, you can clearly identify that it is for das-ias (a Joule application, or a Digital Assistant Service), on the BTP subaccount 2199xxxxxxxx.

A Joule Sign-In Window Pops Up when the SSO Fails

After you enter your username and the password, Joule will launch for you. But it is tedious as each time you need to enter the user credentials when accessing Joule.  That’s the reason we want to use SSO to bypass the sign in process and have a better end user experience.

Note: In one of my recent setups, the SSO didn't work. By looking at the Domain entry, it was blank.  In other words, my Domain selection was not saved.  That could be another cause of SSO doesn't work.

 

Step A.5 Blog1: 7.1 Trust the Public Cloud Tenant Domain in Your BTP Subaccount

In Blog 1 Joule – End-to-End Setup Guide (for all Line of Business) Unified Approach and SAP Help Joule onboarding guide, they all discussed building trust domains in Identity Authentication Service Tenant and the BTP subaccount. But I don’t see this step in the Discovery Zone.

For this step, I added my SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition tenant’s URL here as I don’t have other applications for this configuration.  If you have multiple applications, you can either list them separately or use a wild card like *.cloud.sap. 

Note: Leave the “https://” here to be a full URL (Uniform Resource Locator) or address of your application tenant.

Add the Public Cloud Tenant to be A Trusted Domain in the BTP Subaccount

 

Step A.6 Blog1: 7.2 Trust the Public Cloud Tenant Domain in SAP Cloud Identity Services

For this step, I added my SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition tenant’s URL here as I don’t have other applications for this configuration.  If you have multiple applications, you can either list them separately or use a wild card like *.cloud.sap. 

Note: Don’t leave the “https://” here, because you need to add a host name here.

Add the Public Cloud Tenant to be A Trusted Domain in CIS

Note: This step is also discussed Step B.2 DC2: Validate SAP BTP configuration after Joule Booster Execution.

 

Step A.7 DC1: Create SAP Build Work Zone Instance and Subscription

The SAP Build Work Zone enables Joule as an add-on to run on the Public Cloud Fiori Launchpad. For that reason, we need to create an SAP Build Work Zone Instance and subscribe to it. That’s the purpose of this step.

There are several key points when creating an SAP Build Work Zone Instance:

  1. Although not mentioned, you need to create the subscription first, then the instance in this step. 
  2. Give an easy-to-understand name for the SAP Build Work Zone Instance. I use WZ_instance.
  3. Choose “standard” instead of “foundation” Plan, because we create the Work Zone instance for Joule which requires a standard plan.
  4. Create a Service Key with a meaningful name. The information in the Service Key will be used later in Step B.6 to access the Work Zone.  You download it to a local drive.

 The Created SAP Build Work Zone Instance

At this stage, when clicking on the Work Zone inside the blue box, you will get a logon failure.  Because we haven't assigned a Work Zone Launchpad Admin role to you yet.  This will be done in Step B.3.  I will discuss other topics related with this Work Zone Admin Site Manager Window in Step B.8.

From BTP Global Account, you can also find the work zone is created as a system as discussed in 9.4 Validate the Systems in Blog1 Joule – End-to-End Setup Guide (for all Line of Business) Unified Approach.  This step is not mentioned in Discovery Center document Establish a Unified Joule Instance.

The Work Zone is Registered as a System in the BTP Global Account

 

Step A.8 SH: Configure User Attributes for Joule from the Identity Directory

Because we are going to use the SAP CIS to authenticate for Joule and Work Zone, we need to be sure the SAP CIS is set up correctly.  This step is only discussed in SAP Help Configure User Attributes for Joule from the Identity Directory. 

When a user is authenticated in the SAP CIS, its user attributes are sent to the application requesting the authentication.  There are six user attributes available.  This step is to ensure all of them are selected and sent to the application. If not, add new ones.  From my experience, the attribute Email_verified is frequently missed. The following figure shows all attributes of a user in the SAP CIS, User Management.  Red arrows point to all six user attributes but “groups”.  If this Email_verified user attribute is missing, it is treated as not verified by the application.  The SSO logon will fail.

User Attributes in the SAP CIS

With above knowledge in mind, let’s check/modify attribute(s) for two applications. The application das-ias is for Joule and there is no need to modify, because the Work Zone will do the work.

  • BTP subaccount PSCC-AMER-3SL-PRD
  • SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition

The following is the screenshot of the Application – BTP subaccount PSCC-AMER-3SL-PRD.  The user attribute Email_verified needs to be added by clicking the Add button.

The User Attributes in the Application – BTP subaccount PSCC-AMER-3SL-PRD

The following is the screenshot of the Application – SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition.  I added user attribute Email_verified as part of Self-defined Attributed.

The User Attributes in the Application – SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition

Note: In the SAP Help documentation, the value of groups is listed as “Groups”, but in the system, it is “All Groups” as shown above.  Don’t be surprised because you cannot find the value of “Groups”.

 

Conclusion

In this blog, I explained reasons and catches of all the steps outlined in the Discovery Center 1: Establish a Unified Joule Instance and Discovery Center 2: Activate Joule with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.  After some post Joule Booster running steps, you are on your way to launch Joule in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

 

References

  1. Discovery Center 1: Establish a Unified Joule Instance
  2. Discovery Center 2: Activate Joule with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  3. Blog 1: Joule – End-to-End Setup Guide (for all Line of Business) Unified Approach
  4. Blog 2: Joule in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Setup Guide
  5. SAP Help: Joule onboarding guide
  6. My Blog: My AI Experience Sharing – Setting up Joule for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (Part A Preparation)
  7. My Blog: My AI Experience Sharing – Setting up Joule for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (Part B Joule Installation)
  8. My Blog: My AI Experience Sharing – Setting up Joule for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (Part C Joule Deinstallation)

entry.title: My AI Experience Sharing – Setting up Joule for the S/4HANA Public Edition (Pt B:Joule Installation)
entry.content:
Introduction

Now Artificial Intelligence (AI) is on every professional’s mind. Everybody wants to be on the bandwagon.  I plan to write a series of blogs on this topic under a big umbrella “My AI Experience Sharing”.  This is the first mini-series: setting up Joule for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. 

I purposely delayed my action on setting up a Joule to wait for the dust settling down during the Early Adopter phase. The intention paid off but still won’t give me a free pass 😉. There are five credible references available as listed in the Reference section, but none of them give you a good explanation on Why, especially on What in a critical step with a readable picture when you desperately need a hint.  To help all the people like me, this blog will focus on explaining those steps, what to enter, and possible mistakes to avoid. 

Note 1: The content here is drawn from my direct experience from setting up Joule for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (more than five times and still counting). It might be true for other SAP solutions but only use that as a reference so that I don’t feel the pressure of entire SAP world on my shoulder 😁.

Note 2: Since there are a lot of topics to discuss, I divided the mini-series into Part A Preparation,  Part B Joule Installation and Part C Deinstallation. 

Note 3: The systems I used in this mini-series are:

  • BTP Global Account: 2024-09 3SL Account
  • BTP Joule Subaccount: PSCC-AMER-3SL-PRD
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Production tenant G4X/100, http://myxxxxxxx.s4hana.cloud.sap/ 
  • Cloud Identity Services: Provisioned together with above BTP and Public Cloud tenants, xxxxxxxx.accounts.ondemand.com

Note 4: Considering some customers and consultants need to deinstall and reinstall Joule for many reasons like practicing the installation, correcting an unsuccessful installation, etc., I am adding a new blog Part C: Deinstallation here for your reference.

 

Ten Major Joule Installation Steps Explained

In this section, I am going to explain all ten Joule Installation Steps.  The hyperlink of each step gives a direct access to the document.

We can group Joule Installation Steps into four categories:

  • Step B.1: Run Joule Booster
  • Steps B.2 – B.4: Validate the results of running Joule Booster, make some updates accordingly.
  • Steps B.5 – B.9: Setup an infrastructure and provision/replicate users/groups from the Public Cloud to the Work Zone
  • Step B.10: Test your Joule

 

Step B.1 DC1: Run Booster in SAP BTP for Joule

Within SAP BTP, there is a concept called formation, which is a logical grouping of SAP systems, specifically designed for event sharing within a business scenario.  The Joule Booster groups four systems into one formation for the business scenario of Running Joule on the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: SAP Cloud Identity Services, SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP Build Work Zone, and Joule.  Refer to the picture in Step B.2.1 Check the Formation Created by the Joule Booster.

The Joule Booster is to automate the formation creation process, including communication related infrastructure. Here is the final Review page before executing the Joule Booster.

Review Page of the Joule Booster

Note: From April 9, 2025, our BTP colleagues made an improvement in the Joule Booster. Now there are two versions available, "Setting Up Joule (Internal Prod)" and "Setting Up Joule". The former one is for SAP internal setup usage, and later one is for customers and partners.  There are different entitlement requirements for each of them.  I waited one entitlement for weeks to run the "Setting Up Joule (Internal Prod)".  Hope this won’t be the case for you.

 

Step B.2 Post Booster Configuration

At the end of Discovery Center Establish a Unified Joule Instance and the beginning of Discovery Center Activate Joule with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, there are two very similar steps: Post Booster Configuration for the former, and Validate SAP BTP configuration after Joule Booster Execution for the later. Some work is redundant, but you need to follow Post Booster Configuration first, then Validate SAP BTP configuration after Joule Booster Execution.  Because there are critical steps in Post Booster Configuration to create NavigationService destination, etc. 

In one installation exercise, I tried to launch the Work Zone link in the Instances and Subscriptions, I got an error message: "Uh oh…We can’t seem to find the site that you’re looking for. Either the site doesn’t exist or it’s temporarily unavailable.”  The reason is that the system needs to use the Portal Service URL definition stored in the NavigationService destination to access https://portal-service.cfapps.eu12.hana.ondemand.com/resources/portal/sap/cf/pages/siteNotFound/siteNotFound.html. 

B.2.1 Check the Formation Created by the Joule Booster.

Within the Joule formation, all four systems should be included (shown in the picture of above).

The BTP Formation for the Joule Running on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

Depending on your business needs, you can add another SAP solution into it.  For example, if you add a SuccessFactors system here, both SuccessFactors and Public Cloud share the same Joule.

B.2.2 Check Joule Subscription and Destinations setup in BTP Subaccount

Joule subscription was created as part of the Joule Booster execution.  This step is to test a user can logon to the Joule application.  The URL is like this https://pscc-amer-3sl-prd-xxxxxxxx.eu12.sapdas.cloud.sap/. As you can see in this string, the first part is my subaccount name PSCC-AMER-3SL-PRD. The second part xxxxxxxx is the Joule’s system ID (partially).  The last part is the subdomain.  In the Post Booster Configuration, it was listed as “4m8qi0do”. The last part indicates the data center is located in Europe (e12), and it is a Joule system (sapdas).

Note: when you launch the Joule application for the first time here, a new user with a cryptic ID is created (see the user discussion in Step B.3.2 Content Provider). That's another reason Step B.2 needs to be executed before B.3.

B.2.3 Check If Destinations Are Created Successfully

In Validate SAP BTP configuration after Joule Booster Execution, it lists six destinations.  In my case, only four destinations are created by the Joule Booster as shown in the picture.  There are no Navigation Service nor Runtime destinations there as described

  • Design Time Destination - (with _dt in the name)
  • Runtime Destinations (Not there)
  • Runtime Data (with _rt_data in the name)
  • Runtime Default (with _rt_default in the name)
  • S4HANA_PUB_SSO
  • Navigation Service (Not there yet. Wasn’t created automatically)

Four Destinations Created by the Joule Booster

B.2.4 Create NavigationService Destination

To complete this step, we need to use the Service Key created in the Step A.7 Create SAP Build Work Zone Instance and Subscription.  My NavigationSerivce definition is shown below as a reference.

NavigationService Properties

For your convenience, I am listing the entry mapping between Service Content Key and the NavigationService definition.

Work Zone Service Key File Content

Navigation Service Properties

Notes

 

Name: NavigationService

 
 

Type: HTTP

 
 

Description: can be anything

 
 

Proxy Type: Internet

 

“portal – service”

URL

Including https://

 

Authentication: OAuth2UserTokenExchange

 

“clientid”

Client ID

 

“clientsecret”

Client Secret

 

“url”

Token Service URL

Add /oauth/token toward the end of the string, with leading https://

 

After saving the destination, click on the button Check Connection.  I got an error 404 in the first time.  This indicates a web page cannot be found.

Error 404 when Checking Navigation Service Connection

There are two URL’s in the destination definition.  The first one is https://portal-service.cfapps.eu12.hana.ondemand.com.  When I enter it in a Web Browser, it returns 404 error:

               404 Not Found: Requested route ('portal-service.cfapps.eu12.hana.ondemand.com') does not exist.

This NavigationService is a mystery to me.  In the Solution Architecture diagram (see the beginning of the Part A Preparation Blog), there is a Navigation Target Mapping within the BTP box.  It is used by the Work Zone to fetch roles and available navigational targets, kind of like a look up table. Therefore you don't execute this connection directly. 

At the beginning of Step B.2, I presented an error message due to the absence of NavationService destination. 

The second URL is the Token Service URL. That one works when posting directly in a Web Browser.

B.2.5 Update Application Configuration in SAP Cloud Identity Authentication Service

This step is to verify two applications created by the Joule Booster das-ias and Document Grounding have the same Conditional Authentication setting.

In below figure, although there is no subaccount name as part of the das-ias application, but the number 2199220a appears in all three applications: das-ias, Document Grounding, and SAP BTP subaccount PSCC-AMER-3SL-PRD. I can comfortably conclude that applications das-ias and Document Grounding are Joule related for my subaccount PSCC-AMER-3SL-PRD.

Three Joule Related Applications in the SAP CIS

All three applications have the same Conditional Authentication setting using Identity Authentication. Joule Booster did a good job!

B.2.6 Update Trusted Domains Settings

This setting is also in the SAP CIS. We already completed it in Step A.6 Blog1: 7.2 Trust the Public Cloud Tenant Domain in SAP Cloud Identity Services.

 

Step B.3 DC2: Validate SAP BTP configuration after Joule Booster Execution

B.3.1 Check SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Destinations setup in BTP Subaccount

This step is the same as B.2.3 Check If Destinations Are Created Successfully.

B.3.2 Check Content Provider in the SAP Work Zone

The purpose of this step is to find out the name of the Work Zone Channel Content Provider which we will use for later (Step B.8).

In the BTP Cockpit -> Security -> Users, usually you can see a pair of users with the same Username but different Identity Provider.  For example, my name is listed twice: one with a temporary cryptic ID (also called IAS shadow user ID) and another with my email address.  The cryptic user ID is created/updated on the fly when you access the SAP Work Zone or Joule.  During Joule Setup, this cryptic ID is created in Step B.2.2 Check Joule Subscription and Destinations setup in BTP Subaccount when you launch the Joule application.  Its Identity Provider is the SAP Cloud ID Service or IAS.  My last Work Zone logon time is May 23. 

The email address username is used for logon to BTP tenant.   It uses the Default Identity Provider and shows May 27 because I logged on to the BTP on May 27.

Two Parallel Users in the BTP User List

There are six sub-steps listed in the document. I’d like to explain some of these steps:

Steps 1-3: The SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition is the new name for the SAP Launchpad service. So, you will still see the name of Launchpad here and there.  The reason of assigning the Launchpad_Admin role to the cryptic User ID is to prepare this user to access the SAP Build Work Zone as an administrator to read its Content Provider name.  Without this user role, your access to the Work Zone will be denied.

Step 5: This step is to logon to the Work Zone as an Administrator with your username and the password stored in the IAS. The user must have the Launchpad_Admin role assigned.

When you launch the Work Zone, pay attention to the URL: https://pscc-amer-3sl-prd-xxxxxxxx.dt.launchpad.cfapps.eu12.hana.ondemand.com/sites#Site-Directory.  It is in fact the URL in your Service Key file, and you entered it during NavigationService creation in Step B.2.4. 

Step 6: The Content Provider ID will be used in the SAP Cloud Identity Provisioning setup (Step B.9).  It will be part of many names I will point it out later.

 

Step B.4 DC2: Validate and Update S/4HANA Cloud Configuration after Joule Booster Execution

In the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, the integration with other SAP solutions is predefined according to the scenarios, that includes the integration with the BTP. 

For each integration scenario, we have one specific Communication Arrangement defined, which in turn depends on the underlying Communication System.  One Communication System can support one or more Communication Arrangement(s), but not the other way around.  If you want two same type of Communication Arrangement integrates to two solutions, you need to create two different Communication Arrangements (different names but the same type) residing on two different Communication Systems.

Here are two Communication Arrangements for Joule setup:

  • SAP_COM_0647 for Launchpad Content Exposure to SAP BTP Integration
  • SAP_COM_0882 for SAP Digital Assistant Services

Since the Communication Arrangements are created by the Joule Booster, they all use cryptic ID instead of readable names. Sometimes you might have multiple of them. The easiest way to identify the right one is to check its creation/changing date when you run the Joule Booster.

The Joule Booster creates four Communication Systems. Two are used for the above two Communication Systems. The other two Communication Systems are not used by any Communication Arrangements.  I don’t know why Joule Booster creates them.  If you have an insight on them, please comment!

 

Step B.5 DC2: Configure S/4HANA Cloud for User Replication with Identity Provisioning Service

Steps B.5 though B.9 are for provisioning users and roles from the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to the SAP Work Zone instance.  This is very similar as we provision users from the IAS to the Central Business Configuration in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition as I discussed in my blog Deep Dive into the CBC User Authentication and Authorization Concept.

Let me give a quick explanation (referring below figure). SAP Work Zone is a service running on the SAP BTP.  It does not create users and assign user roles within itself. However, when you access Joule (through Work Zone), you are still limited to those apps you have authorizations to access. This is achieved by doing an authorization check within the Work Zone.

Concept of User/Group Provisioning for the SAP Work Zone

To provision users and corresponding roles from the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, we need to prepare a user provisioning infrastructure manually here.  In comparison, the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition has this infrastructure provisioned by the operations team during system provisioning.

Step B.5 is to set up the Identity Provisioning infrastructure, namely the Communication Arrangement and the Communication System. 

Take a note of the newly created Inbound Communication User, including the username and the password. We will use them in Step B.7.  If this Communication User is locked after multiple logon failures, you won’t be able to provision users/groups to Work Zone again, for example, after you add new users and add/remove user roles.

 

Step B.6 DC2: Update Content Security Policy Settings in S/4HANA Cloud

This step is to add the URL of the Joule application to the Trusted Sites list of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition via application Manage Content Security Policy.  This way the Joule can run as an add-on to the Public Cloud and access all of its data and applications.

You can obtain your Joule application URL by going to BTP  Your Subaccount  Services  Instances and Subscriptions  Subscriptions  Application  Clicking on the Joule hyperlink.

Add the Joule URL to the Trusted Site List

 

Step B.7 DC2: Configure Identity Provisioning Service for User Replication to Work Zone

This Step is to make Identity Provisioning Service working.  You do the following:

  • Configure SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition as a Source System in Identity Provisioning
  • Configure SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition as a Target System in Identity Provisioning

The following figure displays The SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Cloud as a New Source System in the SAP CIS.  The communication user is that Inbound Communication User created in Step B.4.   The newly created Source System is S4-myxxxxx-source-joule. 

The SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Cloud as a New Source System in the SAP CIS

When you create a new Target System, make sure your Source System is S4-myxxxxx-source-joule, the one you just created as shown below.  They work in tandem.

The Work Zone as a New Target System in the SAP CIS

Since the Target System is the Work Zone, we need to use the user information stored in Work Zone instance of the BTP (referring Step A.7).

If you don’t have the Service Key file, follow this path: BTP -> Your Subaccount -> Services -> Instances and Subscriptions -> Instances -> Instance  -> Your Work Zone Instance -> Service Keys, download the Service Key file.

The Discovery Zone has a good screenshot to map the Target System creation window and the Service Key file content.  If the picture is too blurry, download it, then enlarge it to be readable!!! It is my tip of the day 😉.

 

Step B.8 DC2: Provision Users and Groups from S/4HANA Cloud to Work Zone

After above Steps B.5 – B.7, we are ready to provision user and group information from the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (Source System) to the Work Zone instance (Target System).  This step uses the Identity Provision Service (IPS) function within the SAP CIS.

 

Step B.9 DC2: Validate User Provisioning in SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition

Besides checking the Provisioning Log in Step B.8, you can also check the results of this provisioning work by doing the following: BTP  -> Your Subaccount  -> Services  -> Instances and Subscriptions  -> Subscriptions  -> Application  -> clicking the hyperlink of SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition.  The Work Zone Site Manage window is launched.

From Content Manager, you can see all the groups provisioned.  The covered text string in the ID Column is the Content Provider ID we explored in above Step B.3.  For example, the ID ~sap.start.xxxxyyy_SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR indicates the role SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR is from Content Provider xxxxyyy. 

Viewing the Provisioned User Roles/Groups in the Work Zone Content Manager

If you click on the ID ~sap.start.xxxxyyy_SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR, it reveals the applications assigned to this Role ID.

Apps Assigned to the Role ID ~sap.start.xxxxyyy_SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR

By clicking on the Settings  -> Identity Provisioning, we can see the individual user information.  The covered text string in the Role ID Column or the Provider ID Column is the Work Zone Content Provider ID we explored in Step B.3.  In other words, these roles are effective in the mentioned Work Zone.

Viewing the Individual User and the Assigned Groups in the Settings -> Identity Provisioning

These two roles match what I have in the Public Cloud as shown below.

Two Business Roles Assigned to My Account

 

Step B.10 Test Joule in SAP S/4HANA Cloud

This is an exciting step of your entire setup journey.

As you can see from my above screens, I only have two Administrator authorizations in this setup. When I open the Joule, it suggests the apps based on my role, such as “Find Security Audit Log Apps”. After I click on it, it did the job for me.

Joule’s Suggestion base on My User Roles

 

Joule Helped Me to Open the Security Audit Log

There are two possible issues you might face:

  1. You don’t see the Joule icon after you setup Joule for the first time. This happens quite often. Don’t worry and it might be caused by old caches in your Web Browser. Try to open an Incognico or Private window and launch your SAP S/4HANA Cloud. If the Joule icon is there, you are good. You can delete old caches in your regular web browser.
  2. You cannot display the Sales Order list in the Joule. Most probably you don’t have the right authorizations.  You should fail at launching any sales order related apps as well as shown below.  Give yourself the right user roles, and re-provision the users from S/4HANA Cloud to the Work Zone as described in Step B.8.

Failed to “Show Sales Orders” due to Authorization Limit to the User

 

Conclusion

In this blog, I explained reasons and catches of all the steps outlined in the Discovery Center 1 Establish a Unified Joule Instance and Discovery Center 2 Activate Joule with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, focusing on the steps running the Joule Booster and post-processes. By following some tips outlined, I hope you can reach your end zone with no or less troubles.

Disclaimer-It is recommended to conduct an SAP IDM assessment to evaluate the feasibility of migrating existing functionalities to SAP IAG, CIS, or GRC Access Control. The approach in this blog is particularly suitable for customers who primarily use SAP IDM for managing access in SAP systems, whether on-premise or in the cloud.In a more complex and heterogeneous enterprise-wide environment, customers are most likely to rely on a third-party identity management solution. Refer this blog that highlights our partnership with Microsoft to position MS Entra as a successor for SAP IDM.

SAP provides a comprehensive suite of identity and access management (IAM) solutions to help customers manage user identities across their SAP applications, both on-premise and in the cloud. These solutions include SAP Identity Management (SAP IDM), SAP GRC Access Control (SAP GRC AC), SAP Cloud Identity Services (comprising Identity Authentication and Identity Provisioning), and the SAP Identity Access Governance (SAP IAG) service.

SAP IDM, the long-standing on-premise IAM solution that has supported customers for over two decades, is approaching the end of its maintenance lifecycle (refer to SAP Note 3268799). Organizations currently using SAP IDM and planning a migration strategy can consider leveraging SAP IAG, SAP Cloud Identity Services (CIS), and their existing SAP GRC Access Control systems to cover identity lifecycle management needs. In many cases, the combination of SAP IAG with CIS—or SAP IAG with CIS and a bridge to SAP GRC Access Control—can replicate most of the functionalities previously handled by SAP IDM.

SAP IAG and SAP CIS are designed to complement each other and are often deployed together in enterprise environments to deliver end-to-end identity and access management.
