entry.title: Developing a SAP FSM extension on SAP BTP CF using Federated Authentication
entry.content:
This article details a step-by-step guide for developing an SAP Field Service Management (FSM) extension on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) Cloud Foundry (CF) with federated authentication.

It is not intended to be a "Best Practices" document, but rather a simple reference. Because it does not cover a wide number of potential scenarios, it should be considered just a starting point.

 

The use case.

When it comes to “Authentication”, to my experience, one of the first errors made when developing an extension for SAP Field Service (FSM) on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) Cloud Foundry (CF), is to assume that since both are SAP products, authentication is implicit. Although it is reasonable way of thinking, it is not true.

Unfortunately, we learn very late, and the hardest way, that such an assumption is incorrect. Commonly, it happens when we have already generated the extension, it has an XSUAA (Extended Services for User Authentication and Authorization) enabled, and we are already trying to install it via the app SAP FSM Extension Management... just at the time the application throws an error that the extension is invalid.

After multiple attempts without figuring out what's going on, we probably will end up contacting SAP support. In most cases, they will recommend checking the Authentication section on the official SAP documentation portal or suggesting that the extension should be made publicly available on the internet. Which is often misinterpreted as a "please disable XSUAA" 😳

It's at this very moment where it looks like we're going to a dead-end road: if we enable XSUAA, we cannot install the extension. If we disable it, then our extension could be accessed from the internet by anyone. Additionally, looking at the official SAP documentation reveals there are several ways to achieve authentication, but none of them seem to align with SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) Cloud Foundry (CF) 😥. Perhaps with frustration, we wonder if there is a way to get authenticated only in the FSM Shell, and then have the rest happen with Single Sign-On (SSO).

 

The solution.

In an scenario SAP FSM <--> SAP BTP CF, is possible logging in the SAP FSM Shell (only once) and letting the rest happen with Single Sign-On (SSO). This, thanks to the SAP IAS (Cloud Identity Services), which is a core component of SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) that provides authentication services and identity management in the cloud.

This blog describes the journey step by step, from developing the extension to configuring the Federated Authentication in SAP FSM, SAP IAS, and SAP BTP.

Before getting started, it's necessary to check the following prerequisites:

  • You have SAPUI5 development expertise: Advanced skills are not required but a basic level would be very helpful. You can find a variety of resources on the official website.
  • You have an account on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP): If you don’t have an account, follow this tutorial.
  • You have an account on SAP Field Service Management.
  • You know the SAP Business Application Studio (BAS): Check out the official documentation or join the community.
  • You have set up the SAP Business Application Studio for development: If you have not set it up yet, follow this tutorial.
  • You have a DEV space up and running: If you have not created a DEV space yet, follow this tutorial.

This article is divided into five parts:

  • The development of the extension. Based on SAP Fiori design and SAP UI5.
  •  Integrating the SAP FSM ShellSDK library, which allows interaction between the extension and the SAP FSM Shell.
  • Configuring the Federated Authentication (using OIDC) between SAP FSM, SAP AIS, and SAP BTP.
  • The build and deployment in SAP BTP.
  • The installation process in SAP FSM.

 

Developing the Extension

a. In the DEV space in your SAP BTP Business Application Studio, choose New Project from Template:

b. Select SAP Fiori generator and choose Start:

c. Select Basic from the list of templates and choose Next:

d. Select None from the data source dropdown and choose Next:

e. Leave the default view name and choose Next:

f. Enter the module name, application title, description, and select Yes from the Add deployment configuration options. Then, choose Next:

g. Select Cloud Foundry from the target dropdown and select Yes from the Add application to managed application router options. Then, choose Finish:

h. In the workspace dialog box, choose Add project to workspace:

 

Integrating the SAP FSM ShellSDK library

a. To integrate the SAP FSM Shell SDK library into the extension, it is necessary to load it during the startup (for more information, see ShellSdk Examples). In your extension project, enhance the file /ui5extension/webapp/Component.js with the following code:

// Shell SDK library
sap.ui.loader.config({
    paths: {
        "sap/coresystems/fsm-shell": "https://unpkg.com/fsm-shell@1.20.0/release/fsm-shell-client"
    },
    shim: {
        "sap/coresystems/fsm-shell": {
            amd: true,
            exports: "FSMShell"
        }
    },
    async: true
});

b. Initialize the client by sending a REQUIRE_CONTEXT event to the SAP Shell SDK Host. For more information, see ShellSdk - Library usage sample. Adapt the generated code in the  file /ui5extension/webapp/controller/View1.controller.js, so it looks as follows:

sap.ui.define([
...
    "sap/coresystems/fsm-shell"
...

return Controller.extend("ui5extension.controller.View1", {
    onInit: function () {

        const { ShellSdk, SHELL_EVENTS } = FSMShell;

        const shellSdk = ShellSdk.init(parent, '*');

        shellSdk.emit(SHELL_EVENTS.Version1.REQUIRE_CONTEXT, {
            clientIdentifier: 'fsm-demo-plugin',
        });

...

c. To display some extracted data from SAP FSM, enrich the generated content in the file /ui5extension/webapp/view/View1.view.xml with the following code:

...
        <content>
            <sap.ui.layout:Grid xmlns:sap.ui.layout="sap.ui.layout" id="grid0">
                <sap.ui.layout:content>
                    <ObjectListItem title="account" intro="Account" icon="sap-icon://account" id="account"/>
                    <ObjectListItem title="accountID" intro="Account ID" icon="sap-icon://account" id="accountID"/>
                    <ObjectListItem title="company" intro="Company" icon="sap-icon://factory" id="company"/>
                    <ObjectListItem title="companyID" intro="Company ID" icon="sap-icon://factory" id="companyID"/>
                    <ObjectListItem title="user" intro="User" icon="sap-icon://account" id="user"/>
                    <ObjectListItem title="userID" intro="User ID" icon="sap-icon://account" id="userID"/>
                    <ObjectListItem title="locale" intro="Selected Locale" icon="sap-icon://globe" id="selLocale"/>
                </sap.ui.layout:content>
            </sap.ui.layout:Grid>
        </content>
...

d. Adjust the controller /ui5extension/webapp/controller/View1.controller.js by adding the following code:

...
...
  const oView = this.getView();
...
...
  
  shellSdk.on(SHELL_EVENTS.Version1.REQUIRE_CONTEXT, (event) => {
    const {
      account,
      accountId,
      company,
      companyId,
      user,
      userId,
      selectedLocale,
    } = JSON.parse(event);

    oView.byId("account").setTitle(account);
    oView.byId("accountID").setTitle(accountId);
    oView.byId("company").setTitle(company);
    oView.byId("companyID").setTitle(companyId);
    oView.byId("user").setTitle(user);
    oView.byId("userID").setTitle(userId);
    oView.byId("selLocale").setTitle(selectedLocale);
   });
...

 

Configure Authentication

a. In your extension project, create a file appconfig.json under ./ui5extension/webapp/. This concept is described in the SAP FSM Documentation.

{
    "name": "SAP FSM UI5 Extension",
    "provider": "SAP FSM",
    "description": "SAP FSM UI5 Extension",
    "version": "1.0.0", 
    "icon": "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/SAP-samples/fsm-extension-sample/refactor/samples/login-with-token/frontend/icon.png"
}

b. In the file xs-app.json, disable the xsuaa for the file appconfig.json as follows:

{
    "welcomeFile": "/index.html",
    "authenticationMethod": "route",
    "routes": [
    {
        "source": "^/resources/(.*)$",
        "target": "/resources/$1",
        "authenticationType": "none",
        "destination": "ui5"
    },
    {
        "source": "^/test-resources/(.*)$",
        "target": "/test-resources/$1",
        "authenticationType": "none",
        "destination": "ui5"
    },
    {
        "source": "^/appconfig\\.json$",
        "target": "/appconfig.json",
        "service": "html5-apps-repo-rt",
        "authenticationType": "none",
        "cacheControl": "no-cache"
    },
    {
        "source": "^(.*)$",
        "target": "$1",
        "service": "html5-apps-repo-rt",
        "authenticationType": "xsuaa"
    }]
}

c. Get a SAP Cloud Identity Service Tenant:

  • In the SAP BTP cockpit, navigate to your sub-account Entitlements and check if you have an item Cloud Identity Services. If you don’t have it, choose Edit, then Add Service Plans. In the pop-up search for Cloud Identity Services, select the default service plan, and then choose Add Service Plan. Finally, save the changes on the Entitlements page:

  • Navigate to Services, then to Service Marketplace and select the item Cloud Identity Services. On the top-right corner, in the Meatball menú of the tile [...], choose Create.

  • In the pop-up, from the Service dropdown list select Cloud Identity Services. From the Plan drop down list select default. Then choose Next:

  • Leave the Instance parameters as Form (default value), and from the Service Type dropdown list select the value that suits your use case. For this blog, I have chosen Test.

  • Choose Next, review the configuration and choose Create.

  • After a short while, a subscription to the SAP Cloud Identity Service Tenant should appear in the list of Services ==> Instances and Subscriptions, in the SAP BTP Cockpit. You should also receive an email to confirm your account for the Administration Console of the Identity Authentication Service.

d. Set the Trust and Federation between the SAP Authorization and Trust Management Service and the SAP Cloud Identity Service:

  • In the SAP BTP cockpit, under Security ==> Trust Configuration choose Establish Trust.

  • In the pop-up choose the SAP Cloud Identity Service Tenant, then choose Next.

  • Choose the domain configured with the SAP Cloud Identity Services Tenant and continue with Next.

  • If needed, change the name, description, origin key, and link text for user logon of the tenant. Otherwise leave it as proposed by the wizard and continue with Next.

  • Review the configuration and choose Finish.

  • Set to inactive the Default Identity Provider: select the action item from the list, in the details panel choose Edit, uncheck the option Available for user Logon, then choose Save

e. Configure the Federated Authentication with OpenID Connect (OIDC), as described in the SAP FSM Documentation.

1. Register your SAP FSM Account as an Application in the SAP Cloud Identity Services Tenant:

- Open the IAS Admin UI, go to Applications & Resources, choose create, add a new entry as follows, then choose create:

- In the new Application, navigate to the section Single Sign-On ==> OpenID Connect Configuration. Choose a Name, maintain the Redirect URI, and choose Save.

The URIs depend on the SAP FSM cluster:

DE: https://de.fsm.cloud.sap/api/oauth2/v2/authorize

AU: https://au.fsm.cloud.sap/api/oauth2/v2/authorize

IE: https://eu.fsm.cloud.sap/api/oauth2/v2/authorize

US: https://us.fsm.cloud.sap/api/oauth2/v2/authorize

CN: https://cn.fsm.sapcloud.cn/api/oauth2/v2/authorize

- In the new Application, navigate to the section Single Sign-On ==> Subject Name Identifier. In the Primary Attribute Choose Email, and then choose Save:

2. Create an OIDC Configuration (SAP IAS and SAP FSM)

- In the IAS Admin UI, navigate to the new Application, then to the section Application APIs ==> Client Authentication ==> Secrets, choose add, maintain the new secret as shown below, then save.

Make sure you keep a copy of the generated Client ID and the Client Secret in your favorite notepad:

- In the IAS Admin UI, navigate to Applications & Resources ==> Tenant Settings, then go to the section Single Sign-On ==> OpenID Connect Configuration. From the details, go to the section Identity Provider Settings and copy the following Endpoints in your favorite notepad:

- Authorization Endpoint

- Token Endpoint

- Logout Endpoint

- Login to the SAP Field Service Management Admin App with your account. Make sure you have enough rights to maintain configurations.

- Go to your account details, navigate to OpenID Connect Configuration, then create a configuration as follows:

- Name: any name of your choice

- IDP Client ID: the one copied from the SAP IAS Admin UI

- IDP Client Secret: the one copied from the SAP IAS Admin UI

- Authorization Endpoint URL: the one copied from the SAP IAS Admin UI

- Token Endpoint URL: the one copied from the SAP IAS Admin UI

- End Session Endpoint URL: the one copied from the SAP IAS Admin UI

- Fixed Redirect URI: the one used in the OpenID Connect Configuration in the SAP IAS Admin UI

3. Configure OIDC as the default Authentication Method for your SAP FSM Account:

In the SAP Field Service Management Admin App, navigate to your account details, choose Edit, then scroll down to the section Security, in OpenID Connect Configuration choose the one created previously, and then choose Update:

4. Test your configuration:

- Have a "testing user" in your SAP IAS Tenant which is active and has the email address confirmed:

- Have the same "testing user" active in SAP Field Service Management with the same email as the one created in the SAP IAS tenant. The email address should be assigned only to this user, and the role SUPERUSER should be also assigned.

- Visit the SAP FSM Shell login page https://de.fsm.cloud.sap/shell/#/login, type in your account, then choose Continue.

- You should be redirected to the Identity Provider. Type in the email address of the "testing user", the corresponding password, and choose Continue.

- You should login to SAP Field Service Management.

5. In your sub-account in the SAP BTP Cockpit, navigate to Security ==> Settings, then to Trusted Domains, choose Add to register the domain of the Cluster where your SAP FSM account exists. For example, for DE it should be https://de.fsm.cloud.sap 

 

Build, Deploy, and Test the Extension

a. Build: in the SAP Business Application Studio right click over the file ./ui5extension/mta.yaml and choose Build MTA. Once the building is finished, the folders ./ui5extension/dist and ./ui5extension/mta_archives/ should be generated.

b. Deploy: right click on the file ./ui5extension/mta_archives/ui5extension_0.0.1.mtar and choose Deploy MTA Archive.

c. Test: make sure you have a subscription to an "application plan" of SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition in the SAP BTP Cockpit:

Click on the extension:

It should open the SAP UI5 application (the extension) in a new browser. Make sure you copy the url in your favorite notepad, you will need it during the installation process in the app SAP FSM Extension Management.

Note that if you are using chrome, if you open the URL of the extension in a new browser in Incognito Mode, you should be redirected to the Identity Provider where you need to type in the email address of the "testing user", as well as the corresponding password. Then the SAP UI5 application should look like this:

 

Registering the extension in SAP FSM

a. Login to your SAP FSM account with your "testing user". From the Shell home screen, navigate to the Foundational Services app, then to Extensions ==> Installed, and choose Add Extension.

b. When asked for the Access URL, use the one copied in your favorite notepad while testing the extension on SAP BTP, then choose Next.

Make sure you remove the ending index.html from the URL. It should look something like this:

c. The extension details should be pulled from the appconfig.json provided in the extension. Choose Next Step:

d. Finish the installation process by following the next steps. For more information, see Manually Installing an Extension.

e. Assign the extension to the outlet position of your preference. For more information, see Placing an Extension.

The extension should be shown and it should have not required any extra authentication:

I hope it helps you improving your development experience, and if you have any comments or questions, please feel free to share it in the comments section.

entry.title: How IAS and IPS Help Secure SAP SuccessFactors
entry.content:
Hey SAP Community! If you're like me, you're always trying to make business apps easier and safer to use. Today, I want to chat about two tools that help with that: Identity Authentication Service (IAS) and Identity Provisioning Service (IPS). They’re big players in SAP, especially for managing users in SAP SuccessFactors. But what do they actually do, and why should you care? Let’s break it down!

What is IAS?

Think of IAS like the front door to your apps. It makes sure only the right people get in. IAS helps you by letting users log in once and access everything they need without logging in again (that's called single sign-on or SSO). Plus, you get to pick how users log in, whether it’s with a password, a social media account, or even using two steps for extra security.

Cool Things IAS Can Do:

  • Easy Login (SSO): Users love not having to log in over and over on different apps. It's super convenient.
  • Extra Security: You can require more login checks based on who the user is or where they are logging in from. This keeps your apps safe.
  • Works with Other Services: Got Microsoft Azure Active Directory? No worries. IAS can talk to these outside services so everything works together smoothly.
  • Manage Setup with API: Using the tech behind IAS, you spend less time tweaking settings and more time using your apps.

IAS is like the guard at the entrance, keeping everything secure without making it complicated.

Getting to Know IPS

Now onto IPS! It’s not just a fancy name. If IAS is the front door, IPS is the key that makes sure everyone has the right access. It makes managing user identities simple across both cloud systems and systems running internally on your company's hardware.

Cool Things IPS Can Do:

  • User Management: IPS jumps in after you're set up with IAS to ensure everyone gets the right access on all platforms. Think of it like your personal assistant for user access.
  • Data Control: You don’t need all data everywhere. With IPS, you can control what goes where and tailor it to your needs.
  • Transparency and Notifications: IPS keeps you informed with logs and notifications about what's happening with user provisioning. You always know what's going on.

 

 

 

IPS works quietly behind the scenes, giving users access smoothly without manual hassle.

Why IAS and IPS Matter

You might be thinking, "Do I really need these services?" Absolutely, yes! SAP wants to make sure identity authentication is simple and pre-configured in their systems. This means less worry about user access.

IAS can also manage other identity providers, integrating them easily into your workflows. You get strong security and ease in one package.

Setting Up IAS/IPS

Wondering how to set this up? You’re not alone. IAS/IPS comes with many SAP cloud services, but you can also set them up through SAP Business Technology Platform. The best place to start is SAP's Tenant Discovery link to see if you have them ready.

Customizing and Using IAS/IPS

After setup, you can customize login pages, email templates, and usage terms. Check out SAP’s help documents for detailed guides on making the most of IAS/IPS:

  • Identity Authentication Help Documents
  • Identity Provisioning Help Documents

 

Wrapping Up

So there you have it, a simple look at why IAS and IPS are key for SAP SuccessFactors and other SAP cloud systems. They make life easier for you and your users, ensuring smooth and secure access. I hope this helps you understand these great tools better. Until next time, keep your identities safe and your systems secure!

entry.title: SAP Business Technology Platform(BTP) Security Best Practices: Expert Tips to Protect Your Platform
entry.content:
Heard about those big cyber-attacks recently? No names needed, but chances are, your weekly shop has been hit. The interesting thing is that they followed a familiar pattern. Security analysts found that over 52,000 new vulnerabilities were disclosed in 2024, indicating that outdated or misconfigured systems are a growing invitation to attackers (sentinelone.com). Hackers often slip in via a ‘side door’: an unpatched server, an ill-configured cloud service, or a tricked user giving up a password. Another analysis of supply-chain incidents found that about half were driven by stolen or weak credentials (securityinfowatch.com). In plain terms, cybercrooks lean on low-hanging fruit - phishing, reused passwords, forgotten updates , more than any sci-fi-style hack.

Naturally, this has SAP customers asking: “Are our own SAP BTP environments secure? Is our user management tight? Are we following cloud security best practices?” These are great questions, and we’ve been hearing them a lot. So in this blog post we tried to answer these burning questions. We will address everything from locking down user accounts to broader security best practices, and we promise it won’t be a parade of jargon or doom-and-gloom. 

What can we learn from the recent cyber-attacks in the UK?

The recent cyber-attacks targeting major UK retailers mark a significant moment in cyber security as these are among the first Distributed Denial-of-Service (DDoS) attacks to penetrate networks that were protected by enterprise-grade firewalls. In many cases, these firewalls are managed by hyper scalars such as AWS, Microsoft Azure, or Google Cloud, who provide the foundational infrastructure.

However, it’s important to recognise that responsibility for security is shared. There’s a fine line between what the hyper scaler secures and what platform providers, like SAP BTP or Microsoft Power Platform, are responsible for. Most organisations today operate across multiple platforms, each with its own security model, tools, and SLAs, which can lead to gaps in the overall defence posture if not carefully managed.

It’s also a reminder of the real-world consequences of cybersecurity failures. When breaches occur, especially those involving customer data, organisations face not just supply chain or reputational damage, but significant financial penalties under regulations like GDPR. We’ve seen this play out repeatedly, including with major social media companies in recent years.

These all point to the importance of a well-coordinated, multi-layered security approach. It’s got to be holistic and span infrastructure, platforms, and application layers, with clear roles and responsibilities.

How secure is SAP BTP out of the box, and what are the most common gaps you see in customer configurations?

So, that’s the approach, but how is this carried out? The Business Technology Platform is designed with security and governance in mind across multiple layers. Out of the box, SAP BTP offers:

  • Built‑in Identity & Access Management (IAM) & Network Security: Native support for Single Sign On(SSO) /Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA), Role Based Access Control(RBAC), and the SAP Authorisation Management service. Only authorised users and roles can access each sub-account or application.
  • Encryption & Transport Security: All user traffic is TLS-encrypted , and SAP exclusively establishes encrypted communication channels by default.
  • Monitoring & Audit: SAP BTP automatically logs admin and user activities. The Cloud Foundry Audit Log Viewer service lets you review all operations (applications created, users added, etc.), and connect these logs as desired.
  • Secure Development Tools: SAP’s Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) and other frameworks include built-in security guards (XSRF tokens, JWT checks, etc.), plus tools like the SAP Code Vulnerability Analyser (CVA) that statically scan ABAP code on SAP BTP before deployment.

However, despite this strong foundation, we often see gaps in how customers configure their environments. The most common issues include:

  • Bypassing SAP BTP Connectivity Guidelines Customers sometimes integrate third-party APIs or services directly, without using the secure connectivity mechanisms provided by SAP BTP. This can create vulnerabilities and reduce visibility over traffic flows.
  • Improper Credential Management Instead of using SAP BTP’s built-in credential stores, credentials are sometimes hardcoded or stored in less secure ways, leaving applications open to compromise.
  • Neglecting Secure App Design Principles Applications are not always developed using the security best practices. This can lead to poor access controls, exposure to common vulnerabilities, or lack of proper authorisation checks.

While SAP BTP provides a secure foundation, maintaining a strong security posture requires careful configuration and adherence to recommended best practices, particularly when it comes to connectivity, credential management, and application architecture.

How to prevent similar attacks when running business-critical workloads on SAP BTP?

To safeguard business-critical workloads on SAP BTP, a few key practices should be followed:

  • Use SAP Services for All Integrations: Ensure every integration and API call goes through SAP’s connectivity and security layers. Use the SAP Destination Service, API Management, and the Cloud Connector/Connectivity Service, rather than hard‑coding endpoints. This way, TLS is enforced and flows are logged and constrained. (Think of SAP BTP services like a secure gateway that you should not bypass.)
  • Enforce Multi-Factor Authentication Everywhere: Require MFA for all user logins – not just admins. SAP Cloud Identity Service (or your corporate IdP) can enforce MFA policies on every SAP BTP access. SAP’s TechEd guide even walks through configuring MFA for SAP BTP apps. This means stolen passwords alone won’t give attackers an easy in.
  • Harden IAM and Accounts: Follow the principle of least privilege. Regularly audit user roles and prune any unused or generic accounts. Disable any unused features like self-registration or social sign-on. Use roles and groups in your Identity Provider (IdP) to ensure people only get the permissions needed for their job.
  • Monitor and Respond to Logs: Subscribing to the SAP Audit Log Viewer (for Cloud Foundry (CF)) is critical. Review logs periodically for anomalies (e.g. logins from new locations, sudden privilege grants). Configure alerts or integrate these logs into your Security Information & Event Management(SIEM). Quick detection can stop an incident in its tracks.

Even doing just these steps drastically cuts risk. In effect, you’re closing the ‘side doors’: every inbound or outbound connection is tracked by SAP, every user action is logged, and strong authentication blocks the common tricks that took down those retailers.

What role does identity and access management play in defending against modern cyber threats in SAP environments?

Identity and Access Management (IAM) is the keystone of SAP BTP security. SAP BTP supports a full identity lifecycle and fine-grained authorisation model:

  • Role-Based Access Control (RBAC): You define roles or role collections in your SAP BTP sub-accounts (and business roles in the ABAP environment) that grant only needed permissions. Then you assign these roles to users/groups. This enforces least privilege, so even if a user’s credentials are compromised, the attacker’s access is limited.
  • Trusted Identity Providers: BTP can federate with SAP Cloud Identity (Identity Authentication Service) or any SAML/OAuth IdP. Once trust is set up, employees authenticate with corporate credentials (with MFA, if you’ve enforced it). This ensures a single point of control over user accounts and policies. IAM integrates with identity providers and defines roles and permissions to secure applications and data.
  • Principal Propagation: When a user calls between SAP systems (for example, a CF app calling an ABAP endpoint), their identity and roles “travel” with the request. This maintains security boundaries across services.

IAM practices help organisations enforce strict access boundaries, maintain compliance, and defend against unauthorised access—whether from external attackers or internal misconfigurations.

How can organisations balance innovation on SAP BTP with the need for robust security and compliance?

Innovation and security are not opposing forces—they must evolve together. As applications built on SAP BTP grow in complexity, the security measures surrounding them must also mature. The more advanced and interconnected your solutions become, the greater the need for enhanced controls, monitoring, and governance.

Organisations that fail to innovate risk becoming obsolete. But equally, those that innovate without embedding strong security and compliance practices expose themselves to serious vulnerabilities. Every new capability, integration, or user touchpoint introduces potential risks that must be addressed as part of the innovation lifecycle.

Training is also key. Ensure developers and admins know SAP BTP best practices. Ignorance may be bliss, but it also breeds vulnerabilities, since human error is often the weakest link. If all personal interacting with the platform are aware of the threats, they can help mitigate them but also spot them. Make security part of your culture and process – every innovation needs to come with corresponding security guardrails.

Sustainable innovation on SAP BTP requires a security-first mindset—where governance, compliance, and threat prevention are integrated into every phase of development and deployment.

Securing your innovation on SAP BTP

The recent cyber-attacks serve as a stark reminder that even the most well-defended systems are not immune to evolving and opportunistic threats. For organisations leveraging SAP BTP to drive innovation, the message is clear: security must be treated as a continuous discipline, not a one-time checklist.

While SAP BTP provides a strong out-of-the-box security framework, real resilience comes from how that framework is implemented, monitored, and adapted. From enforcing secure connectivity and managing access intelligently, to following coding best practices and monitoring audit logs—every detail matters.

To conclude, the balance between innovation and security is not a compromise; it’s a partnership. With the right governance, identity management, and adherence to best practices, organisations can confidently build and scale on SAP BTP—without sacrificing trust, compliance, or control.

Please feel free to share your experiences and thoughts on the similar approaches you might have taken securing your applications on SAP BTP in the comments section.

entry.title: User Login for External Apps with SAP Cloud Identity Services
entry.content:
Introduction

For developers in the SAP BTP ecosystem, the standard path for authentication involves the SAP Application Router and XSUAA. It's robust and deeply integrated. But what if you need to connect a non-BTP application or simply want to experiment with open standards?

This guide demonstrates how to authenticate a standalone Node.js application directly against SAP Cloud Identity Services (CIS) using a standard OpenID Connect (OIDC) flow.

Disclaimer: A Proof-of-Concept, Not a Production BTP Recipe

It's crucial to state this upfront: this approach is for educational and validation purposes. For production applications on SAP BTP, the Approuter/XSUAA model remains the recommended best practice. This method is perfect for learning, prototyping, or integrating external apps.

Part 1: Prerequisites - Setting up SAP CIS and Your Local Environment

Before we write any code, we need to configure our identity provider (CIS) and prepare our local machine.

Step 1: Subscribe to Cloud Identity Services

First, ensure you have a subscription to the Cloud Identity Services application in your BTP subaccount. You can add it via the "Service Marketplace" if you haven't already.

Step 2: Create an OIDC Application in SAP CIS

Navigate to your SAP CIS tenant's administration console. You can typically access this from the "Instances and Subscriptions" page in your BTP subaccount.

  1. In the CIS admin UI, go to Applications & Resources -> Applications.
  2. Click Create Application.
  3. Fill in the application details:
    • Name: localhost-auth-app (or any name you prefer)
    • Protocol: Select OpenID Connect from the dropdown.
       
  4. Add redirect URL.
    This will reveal the OIDC-specific configuration options. For now, we'll set placeholder values for the URIs.
    • Redirect URIs: https://localhost:3000/callback
    • Web Origins: https://localhost:3000
    • Click Save

Step 3: Collect Your Credentials and Issuer URL

Once the application is saved, CIS will generate the necessary credentials. Keep this page open or copy the following values to a safe place:

  • Client ID: A long, unique string.
  • Client Secret: Click the "show secret" icon to reveal and copy it.

    Next, you need the Issuer URL. This is the unique URL for your CIS tenant that OIDC clients use for discovery.

    1. In the CIS admin UI, navigate to Tenant Settings -> OpenID Connect Configuration.
    2. Under Identity Provider Settings, you will find the Issuer URL.

Copy this URL. It will look something like https://.trial-accounts.ondemand.com. For example: https://afsp7XXXX.trial-accounts.ondemand.com.

Step 4: Create a Self-Signed Certificate for Local HTTPS

Our Node.js application will run locally on https://localhost.

To enable HTTPS, which is required for OIDC flows, we need an SSL certificate. We can generate a self-signed one for development purposes using OpenSSL.

Open your terminal and run this command:

# This command creates a key.pem and cert.pem file valid for 365 days.
openssl req -x509 -newkey rsa:2048 -nodes -sha256 -keyout key.pem -out cert.pem -days 365

You will be prompted to enter some information. You can press Enter to accept the defaults. This will generate key.pem and cert.pem in your current directory.

Part 2: Building the Node.js Application

Now we're ready to build the app.

Step 1: Project Setup

Create a new project folder and initialize it.

# Create project directory and navigate into it
mkdir cis-oidc-app && cd cis-oidc-app

# Initialize a Node.js project
npm init -y

# Install necessary libraries
npm install express openid-client@5.1.5 dotenv

# Create our application files
touch app.js .env

Note: We are pinning openid-client to a known stable version (5.1.5) to avoid potential issues with newer releases.

Step 2: Configure Environment Variables

Open the .env file and add the credentials you collected from CIS.

# .env file

# Paste the Issuer URL from your CIS tenant's OIDC settings
CIS_ISSUER_URL="https://afsp7XXXX.trial-accounts.ondemand.com"

# Paste the Client ID from your created application in CIS
CLIENT_ID="your-client-id-from-cis"

# Paste the Client Secret from your created application in CIS
CLIENT_SECRET="your-client-secret-from-cis"

# The port our local server will run on
PORT=3000

Step 3: The Complete, Working Code (app.js)

This is the full code. The key fix for the openid.Issuer is not a constructor error is using await Issuer.discover() instead of the old constructor method.

require('dotenv').config();
const express = require('express');
const https = require('https');
const fs = require('fs');
const { Issuer } = require('openid-client');

const app = express();
const port = process.env.PORT || 3000;

// Environment variables check
console.log('Checking environment variables:');
console.log('CIS_ISSUER_URL:', process.env.CIS_ISSUER_URL);
console.log('CLIENT_ID:', process.env.CLIENT_ID);
console.log('CLIENT_SECRET:', process.env.CLIENT_SECRET ? '*** (configured)' : 'not set');
console.log('PORT:', process.env.PORT);

// HTTPS options
const httpsOptions = {
  key: fs.readFileSync('key.pem'),
  cert: fs.readFileSync('cert.pem')
};

// Custom Issuer configuration for trial account
async function getCustomIssuer() {
  try {
    console.log('Fetching Issuer configuration...');
    
    const issuer = await Issuer.discover(process.env.CIS_ISSUER_URL);
    console.log('Issuer configuration successful:', issuer.issuer);
    
    return issuer;
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Issuer configuration error:', error);
    throw error;
  }
}

// OIDC client initialization
async function initOIDCClient() {
  try {
    const issuer = await getCustomIssuer();
    
    const client = new issuer.Client({
      client_id: process.env.CLIENT_ID,
      client_secret: process.env.CLIENT_SECRET,
      redirect_uris: [`https://localhost:${port}/callback`],
      response_types: ['code'],
      token_endpoint_auth_method: 'client_secret_basic'
    });
    
    console.log('OIDC client initialized successfully');
    return client;
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Client initialization error:', error);
    throw error;
  }
}

// Authentication flow
app.get('/login', async (req, res) => {
  try {
    console.log('Starting login process...');
    const client = await initOIDCClient();
    const authUrl = client.authorizationUrl({
      scope: 'openid profile email',
      redirect_uri: `https://localhost:${port}/callback`
    });
    
    console.log('Generated authentication URL:', authUrl);
    res.redirect(authUrl);
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Login error:', error);
    res.status(500).send(`Initialization error: ${error.message}`);
  }
});

// Callback processing
app.get('/callback', async (req, res) => {
  try {
    console.log('Callback received');
    const client = await initOIDCClient();
    const params = client.callbackParams(req);
    
    console.log('Exchanging token...');
    const tokenSet = await client.callback(
      `https://localhost:${port}/callback`,
      params
    );
    
    console.log('Fetching user information...');
    const userInfo = await client.userinfo(tokenSet);
    console.log('User information retrieved:', userInfo.sub);
    
    res.send(`
      <!DOCTYPE html>
      <html lang="en">
      <head>
        <meta charset="UTF-8">
        <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
        <title>Authentication Successful</title>
        <style>
          body { font-family: Arial, sans-serif; line-height: 1.6; max-width: 800px; margin: 0 auto; padding: 20px; }
          h1 { color: #2e7d32; }
          pre { background: #f5f5f5; padding: 15px; border-radius: 4px; overflow-x: auto; }
          .user-info { background: #e8f5e9; padding: 15px; border-radius: 4px; margin-bottom: 20px; }
          .btn { display: inline-block; padding: 10px 20px; background: #4CAF50; color: white; text-decoration: none; border-radius: 4px; }
        </style>
      </head>
      <body>
        <h1>Authentication Successful!</h1>
        
        <div class="user-info">
          <p><strong>Username:</strong> ${userInfo.name || userInfo.email}</p>
          <p><strong>User ID:</strong> ${userInfo.sub}</p>
        </div>
        
        <h2>User Information:</h2>
        <pre>${JSON.stringify(userInfo, null, 2)}</pre>
        
        <hr>
        <a class="btn" href="/">Back to Home</a>
      </body>
      </html>
    `);
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Callback processing error:', error);
    res.status(500).send(`
      <h1>Authentication Error</h1>
      <p>${error.message}</p>
      <a href="/">Back to Home</a>
    `);
  }
});

// Home page
app.get('/', (req, res) => {
  res.send(`
    <!DOCTYPE html>
    <html lang="en">
    <head>
      <meta charset="UTF-8">
      <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
      <title>SAP CIS Authentication Demo</title>
      <style>
        body { font-family: Arial, sans-serif; line-height: 1.6; max-width: 800px; margin: 0 auto; padding: 40px 20px; text-align: center; }
        h1 { color: #1565c0; }
        .container { background: #e3f2fd; padding: 30px; border-radius: 8px; }
        .btn { display: inline-block; padding: 12px 24px; background: #1565c0; color: white; text-decoration: none; border-radius: 4px; font-size: 18px; margin-top: 20px; }
        .note { background: #fff8e1; padding: 15px; border-radius: 4px; margin-top: 30px; text-align: left; }
      </style>
    </head>
    <body>
      <div class="container">
        <h1>SAP CIS Authentication Demo</h1>
        <p>This demo shows how to authenticate with SAP Cloud Identity Services</p>
        <a class="btn" href="/login">Login with SAP CIS</a>
      </div>
      
      <div class="note">
        <h3>Browser Security Note:</h3>
        <p>If you see a security warning in your browser:</p>
        <ul>
          <li>Chrome: Type "thisisunsafe" in the address bar</li>
          <li>Others: Go to "Advanced Settings" → "Proceed to localhost"</li>
        </ul>
      </div>
    </body>
    </html>
  `);
});

// Development: Skip SSL certificate validation
process.env.NODE_TLS_REJECT_UNAUTHORIZED = '0';

// Start HTTPS server
https.createServer(httpsOptions, app).listen(port, () => {
  console.log('='.repeat(60));
  console.log(`App running: https://localhost:${port}`);
  console.log(`Login URL: https://localhost:${port}/login`);
  console.log('='.repeat(60));
  
  console.log('\n⚠️ Browser Access Instructions:');
  console.log('1. Go to "https://localhost:3000"');
  console.log('2. For security warnings:');
  console.log('   - Chrome: Type "thisisunsafe" in the address bar');
  console.log('   - Others: Click "Advanced" → "Proceed to localhost"');
});

Step 4: Run the Application

You are now ready to test the entire flow.

  1. Run the server from your terminal:
    node app.js
  2. Open your browser and navigate to https://localhost:3000.
  3. Your browser will show a security warning because we are using a self-signed certificate. This is expected. Click "Advanced" and then "Proceed to localhost (unsafe)".
  4. Click the "Login with SAP CIS" link.
  5. You will be redirected to the SAP CIS login page. Enter your credentials.
  6. After successful login, you will be redirected back to your local application, which will display your user information.

Conclusion

This experiment successfully proves that SAP Cloud Identity Services is a fully compliant OIDC provider, capable of securing not just BTP-native applications but any external application that speaks open standards. While the Approuter/XSUAA pattern remains the gold standard for integrated BTP solutions, it's empowering to have this flexibility for prototyping and external integrations.

I hope this detailed guide helps you connect your own applications

entry.title: Q2 2025: Quarterly Release Highlights: SAP BTP Security and Identity & Access Management
entry.content:
In the second quarter of 2025, we released several new features and enhancements. Did you know that you can find all new feature announcements for SAP Cloud Identity Services in the SAP Cloud Identity Services Release Notes on the SAP Help Portal?

Let’s take a look at some of our recent highlights!

Identity Provisioning Service: Job log improvements

The Job Execution Outcome is now displayed on the Job Execution Details screen and included in the job notifications. It appears when delta-read jobs and jobs that fail to read entities from the source system affect the deletion of entities in the target system.
For more information, see Monitor Provisioning Job Logs.

You can now download and view the details of all deleted entities by a provisioning job. To enable this, set the property ips.trace.deleted.entity to true.
For more information, see Manage Provisioning Job Logs and List of Properties.

Identity Directory Service and Identity Provisioning Service: Support for extension schemas towards many SAP business applications

We now support a number of extension schemas, including

  • SAP extension schema for groups
  • Extension enterprise schema for users
  • SAP ODM User Schema Support

You can find details in the SAP Cloud Identity Release Notes.

Extension of the Identity Directory’s SCIM API

The Identity Directory API of SAP Cloud Identity Services now returns the termsOfUse and privacyPolicy parameters. For more information, check Identity Directory API.

In addition, we now support application-specific group assignments. You can find details in the SAP Help Portal chapters on Identity Authentication and the Local Identity Directory.

Management of Corporate Identity Providers via API

Tenant administrators can manage corporate identity providers in Identity Authentication via API. It offers endpoints for CRUD operations (GET, POST, PATCH, DELETE) over the corporate identity providers. See SAP Cloud Identity Services Corporate Identity Providers Directory.

Configuration of Password Expiration Reminder

You can configure the system to show a password expiration reminder on the user’s sign-in page. For more information, check Enable Password Expiration Reminder.

Enabling SAP Secure Login Service for SAP GUI with support for Microsoft Windows mandatory profiles

We added support for single sign-on on shopfloor Windows-based computers that are configured to use a mandatory profile. This protects shopfloor computers with a restrictive mandatory profile while still offering single sign-on support for desktop clients of SAP GUI. You can find more information in the SAP Roadmap Explorer.

Cloud Foundry Login Based on JSON Web Tokens (JWTs)

When building CI/CD pipelines, developers are responsible for managing the credentials used by these pipelines for authentication to external systems. This traditionally requires developers to take care of the lifecycle of the credentials, including secure storage and regular rotation of the credentials, which comes with repeated efforts and might be error-prone.

In his latest blog post, Authenticating GitHub Actions Workflows Deploying to the SAP BTP Cloud Foundry Environment with JWTs, Sebastian Ries explains how to authenticate to the SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry environment from a GitHub Actions workflow using GitHub-issued short-lived JSON Web Tokens (JWTs), eliminating the need for manual secret management and enabling secure, efficient CI/CD workflows.

entry.title: Understanding Identity and Access Management (IAM) in your SAP Landscape
entry.content:
As companies adopt cloud services, hybrid infrastructures, and mobile workforces, traditional security models no longer hold up. That’s where Identity and Access Management (IAM) steps in as a foundational element of modern cybersecurity strategies.

What is IAM?

IAM, or Identity and Access Management, refers to the set of processes, technologies, and policies that ensure the right individuals—employees, partners, customers—have access to the right resources at the right times for the right reasons. It encompasses how users are authenticated, how their access is granted or revoked, and how their digital identities are managed throughout their lifecycle.

In short, IAM is about answering two key questions:

  • Who are you?
  • What are you allowed to do in the system landscape?

Properly implemented IAM safeguards critical systems and data from unauthorized access, minimizes risk, and supports regulatory compliance. It’s a key enabler for digital transformation!

IAM in the Context of the Secure Operations Map (SOM)

In SAP’s Secure Operations Map (SOM), IAM falls under the User & Identity Management domain. This domain addresses how user identities are created, maintained, and authenticated across enterprise systems. It’s closely tied to both operational efficiency and the ability to secure access in a consistent, auditable way.

This positioning reflects IAM’s importance not just as a security function, but as a business enabler. IAM is a central element for maintaining secure, scalable operations across SAP and non-SAP landscapes.

IAM in the Context of the Secure Operations Map (SOM)

Why is IAM So Crucial Today?

IAM has evolved in response to the shifting landscape of IT security. To understand its current importance, it helps to contrast legacy models with today’s Zero Trust approach.

Legacy Security Model: Perimeter-Based Thinking

Traditionally, enterprise security was focused on protecting the network perimeter. Tools like firewalls, intrusion detection systems, and VPNs were used to keep threats out. The assumption was that anything inside the network could be trusted.

However, this model has several flaws:

  • Insider threats remain unmitigated.
  • It doesn’t scale well to cloud or remote access.
  • Once attackers breach the perimeter, they can move laterally with little resistance.

Zero Trust Security Model: Trust Nothing by Default

In contrast, Zero Trust assumes breach as a baseline. It operates on the principle of “never trust, always verify.” In this model:

  • Every user and device must authenticate continuously.
  • Access is granted based on identity, context, and least privilege.
  • Identity becomes the new security perimeter.

This is why modern IAM is more than just a directory or a login page—it's the core of Zero Trust architecture.

Identity becomes the new security perimeter

SAP Cloud Identity Services (SCI): Your IAM Gateway

Within the SAP ecosystem, the primary tool for IAM is SAP Cloud Identity Services (SCI). SCI is not just a technical necessity—it’s a strategic enabler that helps organizations innovate faster and more securely.

What is SAP Cloud Identity Services?

SAP Cloud Identity Services is a suite of cloud-based solutions designed to provide seamless, secure, and scalable identity management across SAP and third-party applications. Its key components are:

  • Identity Authentication Service (IAS): Handles user login and Single Sign-On (SSO), with support for modern authentication protocols like SAML, OAuth, and OpenID Connect.
  • Identity Provisioning Service (IPS): Automates the creation, update, and removal of user accounts across connected systems. Reduces manual effort and risk of human error.
  • Identity Directory: Stores user attributes and acts as a central repository for identity data, enabling fine-grained control over access.
  • Authorization Management: Helps to define and manage fine-grained access policies for SAP BTP applications based on user or business object attributes. Assign policies using group management in the identity directory, either via SAP Cloud Identity Services UI or the SCIM API.

Together, these services allow organizations to unify identity management across cloud, hybrid, and on-premise systems—accelerating time-to-value while improving compliance and security.

SAP IAM integration with SAP Cloud Identity Services

How to Get Started with IAM in SAP?

If you're new to IAM or just beginning your journey with SAP Cloud Identity Services, here’s a roadmap to guide you:

  • Explore the IAM Reference Architectures: Understand the big picture by reviewing SAP’s recommended architectures for IAM: IAM Reference Architectures

  • Get Hands-On with Tutorials: Try out SCI in a test environment to see how provisioning works in practice. You can also start with a mission on SAP discovery center https://discovery-center.cloud.sap/missiondetail/3116/3152/

  • Collaborate Across Teams: IAM is not a siloed effort. Talk to your Identity & Access Management colleagues and align on strategies for integrating supported systems. Supported Systems in SCI

  • Involve Experts Early: IAM often reaches beyond the SAP center of competence into enterprise architecture, HR systems, compliance, and even customer experience. Bring in experts who can help you design processes that are secure, user-friendly, and scalable.

Final Thoughts

Implementing IAM is not just about ticking a compliance box or improving login flows. It’s about protecting your organization’s most valuable assets—its data, systems, and people—while enabling agility and innovation.

IAM is a journey, not a one-time project. As you build your foundation with SAP Cloud Identity Services, keep in mind that success depends on both technical integration and cross-functional collaboration.

The important IAM domain of secure authentication will be covered in my next post, where I’ll  share practical tips on how to ensure secure connection works both in cloud and on premises.

entry.title: What's New in SAP BTP – Q2 2025
entry.content:
Q2 was another big quarter for SAP Business Technology Platform. From application development to integration and analytics, we are excited to share how SAP BTP continues to simplify, streamline, and speed things up! Let's dive into some of the top innovations!

App Dev & Automation Highlights 

Simplified SAPUI5 extensions with the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard 

If your business relies on cloud ERP as its IT backbone, you know it may need extensions to meet unique requirements. When built-in extensibility isn’t enough, SAP Build on SAP BTP offers powerful options for custom coding and SAP Fiori UI extensions.  

Now, with the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard, you can create UI extensions directly from your cloud ERP application. By launching the Extensibility Wizard directly from your SAP Fiori application, you are given different options for the type of extension you want to create.

The 'User Interface Extension' lets you either adapt the existing Fiori app or create a new custom application. By setting up your destinations and details in the Wizard, you can either remove sections, add new fields, and create a completely new variant of the application with SAP Build Code and Business Application Studio. Developers and key users can already use it to create custom processes and now, custom user interfaces. 

Watch the video demo (starting at 0:08)  for more insights!   

Learn more:  Simplify SAPUI5 Code Extensions with the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard

Application to Enable Business Users to Manage Decisions

To empower business users to view or maintain decisions within SAP Build Process Automation, we launched a dedicated, purpose-built application that can be accessed directly from SAP Build Work Zone – without the need of IT. 

Business users can access a dedicated application in SAP Build Work Zone to manage decisions within a single project. Users can open the decision table, modify values directly, or import data from Excel and then save their changes, seeing only what matters and making the experience clean and focused. The release of a changed version is only one click away. Any errors are shown in the design console, letting users view the different versions of the project. 

See for yourself in the demo (starting at 2:05)  for more insights!

Learn more 

  • Configure the Stuido Home Application 
  • Using the Studio Home Application

Partner Solutions as an Installable Product on SAP BTP ABAP Environment 

Good news for SAP partners developing apps with SAP BTP ABAP Environment: you can now offer your solution not only as a multitenant Software as a Service solution, but also as an installable product! 

Customers can now install the solution directly in their system as a product. As a part of SAP BTP ABAP Environment, the Landscape Portal supports both delivery options: multitenant SaaS and installable product. 

You can do this in three easy steps:

  1. Build your product with the Register Product app. 
  2. Choose your delivery model: 
    • For multitenant SaaS, configure it in the Maintain Solution app  
    • For installable product, use the Publish Product app. 
  3. Publish your solution to the SAP Store with a PartnerEdge Build contract and an SAP Store enhancement. 

Now customers using SAP BTP ABAP Environment can find your product in the SAP Store and install it into their own system using the Deploy Product option. 

For detailed guidance, watch the demo (starting at 3:42). 

Learn more: Building partner products on SAP BTP ABAP Environment

Integration Highlight

Describe Externalized Parameters of an Integration Flow 

In SAP Integration Suite externalization enables integration developers to define parameters as variables for certain configurations of adapters or flow steps of an integration flow. The values of these parameters can be changed without editing the integration flow, for example, when moving integrations from development or test environment to production. To simplify the understanding of this difficult and technical process, content developers can now provide descriptions directly in the integration flow editor. These can be the potential values, examples or additional details explaining the impact of specific values which will then be visible for guiding through each of the fields in the Configure view. This brings huge potential to improve the maintainability and reusability of your integration scenarios.  

Take a look at the demo (starting at 5:21) and see for yourself! 

Learn more: Externalized Parameters View

Data & Analytics Highlight

Analytical insights in Joule 

Joule, SAP's copilot, now enables you to get quick analytical answers without having to build reports. This provides you with valuable insights, saving time and giving you the information you need. 

Joule scans available data sources and suggests a few options, making comparisons to previous months easier. Joule updates the view right away, making it easy to see how things are trending. For example, you can ask for the top ten sales agents, check the monthly commission trend from January to March, giving you contextual and relevant answers 

See this in action in the demo (starting 7:15).

Learn more: Introducing Analytical Insights in Joule: Empowering Smarter Decisions, Instantly

Cross Platform Highlight

Provision App-Specific Groups in Identity Directory 

SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant enables immediate provisioning of authorizations to target systems in SAP Analytics Cloud target system. You can  centrally manage user-group assignments linked to application-specific policies, triggering provisioning jobs that synchronize access rights efficiently and securely. This ensures users gain prompt access to their designated roles in the target system.

Watch the demo (starting at 8:37) for a closer look. 

Learn more: SAP Cloud Identity Services

Share your thoughts 

These videos are for YOU. We would love to hear your impressions. How do you like the video? How can we improve the upcoming videos? Please share your feedback by liking this post or leaving a comment below.

Thank you for your support and happy viewing, sharing, and enjoying!

entry.title: Configure Single-Sign-On for SAP Ariba with SAP Cloud Identity Services
entry.content:
See as well:
  • Summary: SAP Ariba, SAP Business Network, SAP Fieldglass SSO with SAP IAS
  • Overview: SAP Ariba SSO with SAP Cloud Identity Services - Identity Authentication

Abstract

With the introduction in 2505 release of the feature 'Configure Authentication with SAP Cloud Identity Services for SAP Ariba Solutions in Intelligent Configuration Manager (CFG-324)' , Single-Sign-On (SSO) configuration for SAP Ariba with SAP Cloud Identity Services (CIS) is simplified and further automated, as detailed in this blog post.

Prerequisites

  • SAP Ariba user of type Third Party Enterprise User (Ariba)
  • Customer Administrator group membership
  • S-User ID in SAP for Me

Note: It is strongly recommended to use https as the SAP Ariba SSO SAML 2.0 Issuer, for security reason and for alignment with the auto-generated configuration described below. A support ticket requesting  PS-1444 Feature Toggle is required to enable the use of https in the issuer.

Process

1. Access SAP Ariba Intelligent Configuration Manager (ICM)

Access the SAP Ariba tenant using the Third Party Enterprise User (Ariba) created as part of the prerequisites.

  • Build the login URL appending '?passwordadapter=ThirdPartyUser' to use Third Party User authentication. For example for US Datacenter: https://<SAP Ariba tenant id>.procurement.ariba.com?passwordadapter=ThirdPartyUser
  • Open ICM - Navigate to Manage > Core Administration (for SAP Ariba procurement tenant) / Administration (for SAP Ariba sourcing tenants) > Intelligent Configuration Manager > Manage Configurations > Click Continue button
  • Open the Authentication tab of ICM

 

Note: In case of configuring the SSO setup for SAP Ariba Sourcing, SAP Ariba Contracts, SAP Ariba Supplier Lifecycle and Performance for suite-integrated tenants the SSO setup needs to be executed on the SAP Ariba procurement tenant.

In case of  SAP Ariba Multi-ERP configuration setup (f.k.a Federated Process Control FPC) the SSO configuration needs to happen for the parent tenant. 

2. S-User ID configuration

The S-User ID must be linked to the same organization as the SAP Ariba tenant (and CIS tenant to use if already provisioned), this can be verified by opening the System & Provisioning section of the SAP4Me portal, connected with the S-User and validating that the SAP Ariba tenant (and CIS Tenant if already provisioned) appear as in the below example with SAP Ariba Procurement and provisioned CIS Tenant.

 

 

  • Enter the S-User ID and click Validate - The validation process takes around a minute and requires page refresh to update the status

 

  • Once validated, use the Enable button to enable the site for CIS configuration

 

3. CIS Tenant selection

Depending on the landscape two paths are available :

  • CIS tenant Provisioning - In case no CIS tenant is available, provisioning of a CIS tenant is done from ICM and then auto-configured.
  • CIS tenant Selection - In case CIS tenants are already available, tenant selection is needed for the auto-configuration.

3.a. CIS Tenant Provisioning

Validate and submit the tenant provisioning form generated from the S-User information data.

 

3.b. CIS Tenant Selection

Select the appropriate CIS tenant for auto configuration from the list and submit.

 

Note : Landscape tier alignment is required ie: If SSO is configured on a Test SAP Ariba tenant, selection of CIS with tenant type Test is required, and similarly with Production.

4. Approval

Upon CIS tenant provisioning request (3a) or CIS tenant selection (3b) an approval is required to trigger auto-configuration.

 

  

5. Auto-Configure CIS

Auto configuration process runs upon tenant provisioning / selection showing 'Provisioning in Progress' status, it takes several minutes and generates several artefacts in CIS:

  • SAML Applications Configuration with the SAP Ariba tenant for user authentication over SSO
  • OpendID Applications Configuration with the SAP Ariba tenant for app-to-app connectivity
  • Source and Target systems in Identity Provisioning Service for user and group provisioning

Note : Auto-configuration leverages by default the Login Name attribute of the CIS user as NameID for the SAML assertion, therefore it needs to match the UniqueName attribute of the SAP Ariba user.

 

Note : The Configuration step creates several applications in the CIS tenant with dedicated pattern. In case of a Suite Integrated tenant with Multi-ERP the applications are defined as below:

Parent Realm :

  • Application for SSO on the Parent realm with normalized name <Customer name><SAP Ariba Procurement parent realm name>
  • Applications for app-to-app authentication with normalized names: Sourcing-<SAP Ariba Sourcing realm id> and Procurement-<SAP Ariba Procurement parent realm id>

Child Realm :

  • Application for SSO on the Child realm with normalized name <Customer name><SAP Ariba Procurement child realm name>
  • Application for app-to-app authentication with normalized name  : Procurement-<SAP Ariba Procurement child realm id>

 

6. Activate Configuration

Once auto-configured the system is in 'Ready to Activate' state, click the Activate button to enable SSO.

Confirm configuration acknowledgements.

 Note: Once Activated, SSO configuration cannot be deactivated from ICM, in case deactivation or configuration change is required, a support ticket needs to be raised.

 

7. Test Configuration

Once activated, the SSO configuration is enabled and can be validated:

7.a ICM

ICM configuration should show Activated CIS as well as Enabled SAML Authentication.

 

7.b SAP Ariba web interface access

Access SAP Ariba tenant via its URL in a web browser - for example for US Datacenter: https://<SAP Ariba tenant id>.procurement.ariba.com

Redirection to the configured CIS tenant login page validates correct setup.

 

Redirection to the SAP Ariba login page denotes an issue with SSO configuration.

 

Note : In case of  SAP Ariba Multi-ERP configuration setup, test both the Parent and Children accesses.

Remarks

Note: In case Third-Party SAP Ariba users need to be authenticated by the Identity Provider setup for SAP Ariba SSO, PLAF-1869 Feature Toggle needs to be enabled via a support ticket. Ensure you have the proper Third-Party SAP Ariba users setup in your Identity Provider setup for SAP Ariba SSO as your existing SAP Ariba credentials for Third-Party SAP Ariba users will not be working after the Feature Toggle is enabled. In case of issues accessing SAP Ariba for Third-Party SAP Ariba users via Identity Provider setup for SAP Ariba SSO ask to disable PLAF-1869 Feature Toggle to revert back to the SAP Ariba authentication of Third-Party SAP Ariba users.

Note: In case SSO was configured on the SAP Ariba tenant with CIS prior to the CFG-324 feature release, it is currently not possible to leverage this process, this blog will be update when more information will be available.

  • Summary: SAP Ariba, SAP Business Network, SAP Fieldglass SSO with SAP IAS
  • Overview: SAP Ariba SSO with SAP Cloud Identity Services - Identity Authentication

entry.title: Navigating the Future: Understanding Upcoming Changes to SAP Universal ID
entry.content:
As digital transformation continues to reshape businesses worldwide, identity and user management have become more critical than ever. In this landscape, SAP is evolving how it approaches user identity through significant changes to the SAP Universal ID (UID) framework. These changes reflect SAP’s ongoing commitment to streamlining user experiences while enhancing security across its platforms.

One of the most notable updates: users will no longer log in using their UID. Instead, authentication will now require an email address and a dedicated password. While the UID itself will no longer be used for login anymore, it will continue to serve as an umbrella technology, efficiently collecting and managing all accounts linked under a single UID email address.

This updated authentication process represents a more simplified approach to SAP identity management. This blog post will explore the current state of SAP Universal ID, highlight the recent changes, explain their impact on users, and outline what’s next for the future of SAP identity management.

What Is SAP Universal ID?  

SAP Universal ID (UID) was created to serve as a unified account across all SAP systems, managing and linking various user IDs such as S-, P-, C-, D-, and I-user IDs into one seamless account. This consolidation not only simplified access but also ensured that learning certificates, awards, and reputation badges are retained permanently, regardless of organizational changes.

What's Changing in SAP Universal ID? 

Looking ahead to August 2025, important changes are going to happen to SAP Universal ID. This transition removes UID as a login method and positions it purely as a management tool. Users will no longer authenticate using their UID. Instead, the UID will function solely as a "wallet", enabling users to link and manage all their user identities in the SAP UID Account Manager. Authentication will be handled through these linked accounts, not the UID itself. These broader identity renovation strategy advancements underscore SAP’s commitment to simplifying the user experience across its platforms by creating a more unified, secure, and user-friendly login experience across the SAP ecosystem.

Why Is SAP Making This Change? 

This transformation is part of SAP’s broader identity renovation strategy. As SAP continues to evolve its identity and management solutions, the transition to identity renovation represents a new chapter in digital identity consolidation and management. While SAP Universal ID remains a pivotal part of this strategy, the shift towards SAP IAS sessions highlights the dynamic nature of enterprise technology. For customers and partners understanding and adapting to these changes will ensure optimized digital interactions within the SAP ecosystem. 

The SAP Universal ID will shift roles with the advent of identity renovation. You can learn more about it in the Bring Your Own Identity: SAP's Strategic Transformation of Identity and Authentication Management blog post.
